loans.name: Oscar Manuel

texts.es:
Oscar C.  es un joven dedicado  al comercio de Colonias americanas y a la venta de artesanías  como bolsos y sandalias que trae de San Juan Nepomuceno y de San Jacinto, ambos poblaciones ubicadas en el departamento de Bolívar. A sus 21 años sus padres le dieron su primer capital semilla y empezó vendiendo colonias americanas  y le fue bien con esta primera experiencia, así fue que empezó a atraerle la venta de las bellas artesanías traídas de San Jacinto y San Juan Nepomuceno y logro con una buena administración de su dinero, incursionar e impactar su mercado con estos nuevos productos: sandalias y bolsos elaborados a mano. Oscar aunque  joven es muy emprendedor y tiene  muchas aspiraciones y sueños hacia los que se dirige,  por eso planea continuar sus estudios y en el futuro ser un exitoso empresario profesional, exportador de las artesanías de Colombia, que mucho valora y sabe que son muy apreciadas por los extranjeros que han visitado a su bonita e histórica Cartagena de Indias.  Este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el comprará bolsos y sandalias que tiene encargados y otras artesanías como pulseras y colonias americanas que ya la gente reconoce por la calidad de sus aromas y son muy acogidas.
Oscar es un muchacho alegre e  inspira confianza a  cualquiera que llega a conocerlo, por eso se le facilita el acceso a muchos mercados en todos los niveles sociales y cuenta con una clientela inigualable;  así mismo también sus padres han depositado toda su confianza en sus capacidades , lo han impulsado para que gestione su propio porvenir y lo apoyan en todo lo que le represente una vida llena de éxitos.
texts.en:
Oscar C. is a young man who works as a merchant of American colognes, but he also sells handcrafted products such as purses and sandals that are brought in from San Juan Nepomuceno and San Jacinto. Both of these towns are located in the Department of Bolívar. At the age of 21, his parents gave him seed capital so that he could begin selling American colognes and he did very well with his first experience. Later he began bringing in beautiful handicrafts produced in San Jacinto and San Juan Nepomuceno. As a result of managing his money well, Oscar was able to venture into new markets and expand his inventory with new products such as handmade sandals and purses.

Even though he is young, Oscar is enterprising and has many aspirations and dreams to fulfill. He plans to continue his studies and become a successful business professional in the future. Oscar wants to export Colombian handicrafts since they are treasured and well-known among foreigners who have visited the beautiful and historic city of Cartegena de Indias. With his first loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, Oscar will purchase purses and sandals that he has on order as well as bracelets and popular American colognes that are known for the quality of their scents.

Oscar is a happy young man who inspires confidence in everyone he meets. This quality helps him gain access to many markets across all social levels, thereby accruing a unique customer base. At the same time, his parents have great confidence in his abilities. They continue to encourage and support everything he does so that he can have a successful life.

loans.use: Purchase American colognes, handcrafted purses, sandals, and bracelets

loans.name: Pheam

texts.en: Pheam V., 33, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and three young children. She makes about US$5 daily, selling groceries, while her husband makes US$3 as a moto-taxi driver. She is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase more groceries to expand her current shop. She is also hoping to purchase a pig to raise and sell with the money from the loan. She sees this loan as a great opportunity to expand her business and is confident that she will see her income increase as a result.

loans.use: To expand grocery shop.

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en: Sorm V., 45, lives in the Takeo province with her husband and four children. She makes about US$3 daily, selling chickens at the local market, while her husband makes US$2 as a farmer. She is asking for a loan of US$500 to sell more chickens daily. This couple is also supported by two children who are garment factory workers.

loans.use: To buy and sell chickens.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem V. is 24 years old and lives with his wife in the Takeo province. He is a construction worker building a house and is able to make about US $3 every day. His wife is a garment factory worker and makes US $3 per day as well. Since Sem V. spends a lot on transportation, he is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase a motorbike as his way to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en: Perveen lives in a small city in Pakistan called Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry. She lives in the area of kulley wala in a three-room brick house with her family. She is a very talented lady who operates her embroidery business to share the financial burden with her husband. She doesn’t have any children yet. She is married to A. H., who also operates an embroidery business. In fact, all her family is involved in embroidery. Her brother-in-law and sister-in-law also do embroidery. Her mother-in-law embroiders clothes to increase their value. Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy embroidery items such as beads, colored thread, clothes and laces in bulk quantity. The bulk items will enable him to make more embroidered dresses to improve his embroidery business. He has been doing this business for the past 15 years, and Perveen has great expectations that he will be able to successfully improve his business and increase his household income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years she has proved herself a responsible person who has paid her installments on time and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To buy supplies for embroidery business

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: Razia lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry. She is 34 years old and lives in a two-room house in an area named Kullay Walla with her husband, H. A., and eight children. Six are sons and two are daughters. Only her youngest children are able to get an education. Her first two sons operate a fruit-selling business. Her third son is a cobbler and operates a business of shoe making and selling, while her elder daughter does embroidery work at home. These four contribute to their family financially. Razia operates an embroidery business to share the financial burden with her family. She receives regular orders from different cloth shops and earns money by completing them on time. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who has a timber-selling business. With the loan, he will buy timber in bulk quantity which will help him fulfill larger orders on time and earn a better income for his family. Razia is a regular loan user of Asasah, and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself a responsible person who has paid her installments on time and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To buy timbers in bulk quantity for reselling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction supplies to repair her house

loans.name: Ashran

texts.en: Ashran lives in a small city in Punjab, Pakistan, called Kasur. Kasur is famous for its leather industry. She is 29 years old and married to S. H.. She lives in the area of Kullay Walla in a three-room brick house with her family. She is the mother of two sons and a daughter. Her daughter is in second standard and her older son is in kindergarten. The younger son is only 2 years old. Ashran is a very talented lady who owns and operates an embroidery business at her home. She makes embroidered dresses to sell to cloth markets to supplement the income of her family. She is very good at her art and knows different embroidery techniques to craft unique and beautiful designs on clothes. Her husband is involved in two different businesses. He operates a fruit-selling business and an animal-selling business. He purchases young animals and sells them after raising them. Ashran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to financially assist her husband in his animal-selling business. With the loan, he will buy a good quantity of goats and sell them for a good profit. Ashran hopes that taking a loan and making an investment in her husband’s business will be a good decision for her family’s financial future. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her family and her husband’s income will double.

loans.use: To increase stock for animal-selling business

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en: Perveen is a resident of Kasur, a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and famous for its leather industry. She operates an embroidery business in her home to supplement the income of her family. She is excellent in her art and, due to the quality of her work, she receives regular orders from her customers. By making a good income from this business, she has become an additional earning hand of her family. She is the mother of a son and four daughters. Her son is a daily wage laborer and her eldest daughter helps Perveen in her embroidery business. The remaining three daughters stay at home and manage the household chores. Her husband works in Pakistan railways on a monthly wage. Her brother-in-law also lives with her. He sells fruits from his cart and contributes to the family financially. Perveen has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her brother-in-law. With the loan, he will buy seasonal fruits for his fruit-selling business. Perveen is hopeful that, by making this investment, her brother-in-law will improve his business and increase his income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years she always attended the meetings and paid installments on time.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for fruit-selling business

loans.name: Khalida

texts.en:
Khalida lives in a small city in Punjab called Kasur. Kasur city is famous in Pakistan for its leather industry. She is 29 years old, married to M. S., and has been living in the area of Kullay Walla since her marriage. She has given birth to a son and a daughter. Both are very young, less than 2 years old. 

Her husband has a dairy business. Currently he has three buffaloes at his home and he gets milk from them to sell through his milk-shop. His shop is located in the market where he deals with good number of customers every day and makes good earnings. He is the only breadwinner for his family and by holding this status he always tries to put a step ahead to improve the financial conditions of his family. 

Last year, from his profit he bought a buffalo and increased the milk-productivity of his business. Now he has a plan to buy another buffalo so he can steadily grow his business to a large scale one and provide improved living conditions for his family. 
 
Khalida has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, to buy another buffalo for her husband’s dairy business.  She is confident that her husband will make good use of the loan and the productivity of milk will be increased by purchasing another buffalo, so that will increase his sales and income also. She is a new loan applicant and hopes to build a long-term relationship with Asasah.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Naziran

texts.en:
Naziran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s dairy business.  He wants to improve his milk-selling business by purchasing another buffalo. She lives in a small city, Kasur, famous in Pakistan for its leather industry,  and owns a small house of two rooms in an area named Kullay Walla where she has lived with her family for many years. She is the mother of 5 sons; three of them work and the other two are studying. Her eldest son is a gardener, and the other two works in a factory on monthly wage. 

Naziran is a very caring lady. She prefers to stay at home managing the household chores and taking care of her family. In her spare time she helps her husband by taking care of his buffaloes and milking them as well. With the loan amount her husband will buy another buffalo for his dairy business. Naziran hopes that by purchasing another buffalo, the productivity of milk will ultimately increase which will make her husband more sales and income. 

Naziran has a plan to construct a room in her home for her eldest son because he is nearing marriageable age. She is confident that this will be done soon with the help of loan profits. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In her previous loan years she has always paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en:
Shazia lives in Kasur which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, known for its leather industry. She lives in an area named Kullay Walla in a three-room brick house with her husband. She is 28 years old and married to W. A. who is an animal seller by trade. He buys young animals from the animal markets at cheap rates, rears them, and then sells them to customers, earning good profit on it. He has been doing this business for past 6 years. 

Shazia doesn’t have any children yet, so to pass the time and to increase her household income she does sewing and embroidery work at her home. She makes embroidered clothes for neighboring customers. She is good at her art and gets regular orders.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy young animals (goats & buffaloes) for his business. 

Shazia hopes that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and he will be successfully uplift his business by increasing his sales.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years she has proved herself a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To buy animals for animal-selling business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy different kinds of thread and cloth for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: expand her business by purchasing a modern sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchasing a new frame for her business

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 35 years old. Lucina is married and has 4 children. Her eldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is aged 4. She buys and sells assorted fish in their community. She also dries some fish that she sells. Her family also owns a tricycle that her husband drives to transport people around their community. They also own a jukebox  that her neighbors rent during fiestas and other celebrations. 

Lucina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair their existing vehicle for better service and buy additional fish to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service and buy additional fish to sell

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
This is Melita D., 56, a widow who is now providing for herself and her family. She is a resident of Caloocan City just north of Manila on the island of Luzon. Melita maintains a direct sales business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct sales brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct sales brands. She also sells beauty products to salon, beauty shops and barber shops.

The way in which a direct sales business works is that a customer’s order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, so these are the profits that dealers count on as their income.

Melita’s regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 PHP in sales every week. To help her continue operations, she is requesting a 34,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans. Melita faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Mbuzi Tukorrehamu Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a 26-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is married and has one child aged one year. He looks after the welfare of three people with whom he lives with in a semi-permanent house. He operates a retail shop and is also a farmer. He has been operating his retail shop for the last two years. He hopes to see his retail shop transform into a wholesale shop one day for bigger sales and profit margin.

 For now though, Emmanuel is concentrating on the farmland he has to cultivate and getting better yields this season. He intends to use the loan funds to buy bean seedlings and pay labor for tilling the land for planting.

loans.use: Buy bean seedlings, pay labor for tilling the land for planting

loans.name: Joey

texts.en:
Joey T. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 24 years old. Joey is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Joey owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Joey has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.
 
In 2009, Joey joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joey has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Joey is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Joey from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn T. is from the village of Calamagui. She is 40 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling snacks for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Jocelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Truphosa

texts.en:
Truphosa is a 52-year-old lady who has been in dairy farming for last 15 years in Kiambu. She is married to Daniel Mashehu who is also a farmer. They are blessed with four children, ages 35, 32, 26 and 22. Her monthly income out of this business is 12,500 Kenyan shillings.

She was introduced to KADET LTD. by a church member. She is applying for her second loan with KADET, which she plans to use to buy a dairy cow. Because she does farming on her own piece of land, there is great potential to expand her business with the extra profit she receives.

Truphosa dreams to have the dairy farming activity secure her retirement. She is a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa G. is a 37-year-old hotel (mini restaurant) proprietor in Shimanzi. She is the mother of one and wife to James Nyaber, who is a guard and supports her income. She has been in the business for the last 11 years. With her first loan with KADET LTD., she plans to purchase more stock of foodstuffs for her hotel and to buy new plastic seats. With the anticipated income, she plans to grow her business and to offer better services to her clients. 

Teresa will use the anticipated profit to renovate her hotel and hopes to become successful in life in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of foodstuffs for her hotel (mini restaurant) and buy new plastic seats

loans.name: Ursula

texts.en:
This is Ursula F., 44, who is married to Arnel F. and is the mother of a high school-aged teenager and an elementary school youngster. She is a resident of Caloocan City just north of Manila on the island of Luzon. By the grace of God, Ursula has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to support both of her children and continue sending them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Ursula, as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Ursula operates a buy-and-sell business. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell items piecemeal, thus resulting in a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other such products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low prices and the many options they are offered. She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Ursula dreams of giving her all of her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen belongs to a small city of Punjab called Kasur. Kasur is famous for its leather industry in Pakistan. She lives in the area of Kot Haleem Khan with her family in a two-room brick house. 

She is a 50-year-old homemaker. It is difficult for her to work at her old age; that’s why she stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is a widow and a mother of four sons and a daughter. All of her sons are young and do different work. Her eldest son has a grocery shop in the market, while the remaining three sons have a business of selling leather to their customers. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her elder son’s business. With the loan amount, he will buy groceries such as rice, cooking oil, lentils and spices to sell through his shop. Perveen is hopeful that her son’s business will become better after making the investment into it and that his household income will become increased.
 
He has been doing this business for the past six years and Perveen has trust in her son that he will put the loan amount into his business in the right way.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible person who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

Note: In the picture, the lady who is standing first on the left is Perveen.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda B., photographed with her only baby, is from the town of Talibon. She is 31 years old and married. To make a living, Criselda has a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She does her best to keep the farm productive.

Criselda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes M. is a 28 year-old food kiosk owner and charcoal dealer in Shanzu Mombasa married to Livingstone Nyamawi. She has been in this business for two years and makes a good income. She is requesting her second loan from KADET LTD to purchase sacks of charcoal, bails of maize flour and to carry out renovations in her kiosk.

Agnes has no history with any other MFI. She would use the anticipated profit to expand her business and dreams of opening up a hotel in the future. She is very determined and hard-working lady.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal and maize flour, and renovate her kiosk

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en:
Shabana, with hand raised, is from the small city of Punjab called Kasur, famous for its leather industry. She lives with her family in a three-room brick house where she moved after her marriage to S. A. many years ago. She is a seamstress and sews clothes for neighboring customers. She has a good name in the region due to her ability to produce quality work. She started doing this work five years ago in order to supplement the  family income. Now she receives regular orders every month and earns a good income. Her husband has operated a sweetmeat shop in the market for more than 10 years and has a good reputation for his quality items. Shabana is the mother of two daughters and a son; her eldest daughter is a school teacher and the younger one does embroidery work at home. Her son works in a factory for a monthly wage. They all work to contribute to their family financially. 

Shabana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan her husband will buy items such as milk, sugar, cooking oil and dry fruits in bulk for his sweetmeat business. This will enable him to make sweetmeats in bulk and increasing his sales. She is very confident that her husband will be successful in his business after making this investment in it. 

Shabana is a regular client of Asasah and this is her third loan application. She has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, cooking oil and dry fruits in bulk for his sweetmeat business

loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en:
Gliceria B. is from the village of Brgy. Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Gliceria raises pigs for fattening and sale. Gliceria has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Gliceria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell and is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Gliceria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Bayanmunh

texts.en: Bayanmunh B. lives with his wife and two teenage daughters in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. His daughters both attend the local high school, while his wife works as a cook. Bayanmunh owns a successful taxi service. He has been driving a taxi since 1988 and has gained a lot of experience as a driver. He is a modest, open-minded and hard-working businessman and is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to improve his car that uses as a taxi.

loans.use: To improve his car

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
This is Concepcion P., 56, who is married to Bernard P. and the mother of their one and only child. She is a resident of Caloocan City just north of Manila on the island of Luzon. At this time, she is working hard to be able to support her child and to continue sending him all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Concepcion, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children.

Concepcion operates a smoked-fish vending business. What she basically does is buy a quantity of fresh fish from the market and process them by smoking them until they are ready to sell. She packs these dried fish at prices ranging from 15 PHP, 30 PHP and 50 PHP depending on the quantity of fish per pack. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 200-300 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations, she is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of fish to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Concepcion dreams of giving her child a good and high quality education through her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Oktyabri

texts.en:
Oktyabri B. is 24 years old and lives with his wife and son in Hovd province in western Mongolia. His wife is unemployed and takes care of their small son.

Since 2003 Oktyabri has been working in the construction industry. Since construction work is seasonal, he wants to drive a taxi. He is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan to purchase a car for his taxi business. Oktyabri dreams of saving money from his new business and purchasing his own property.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Zakia's Group

texts.en:
Zakia (pictured with her hand raised) lives in a small city called Kasur, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She is 41 years old and lives in a 2-room brick house with her husband and children. She is the mother of 4 sons and a daughter. Her 2 eldest sons are loaders by trade, and help their father in his loading business, which provides transport facilities to its clients for delivering items to their designated places. Her third son has a leather selling business in the local market, and her remaining children are getting their education from a local school in Kasur. 

Zakia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s loading business. He will use the money to buy new tires to replace the old ones on his truck, which are almost worn out, making it difficult for him to drive the truck and deliver goods. Zakia is hopeful that after buying the new tires her husband will be able to work better and provide better transport facilities to his clients. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 5th loan application. In previous loan years she has maintained good credit and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: to replace the tires on her husband's truck

loans.name: Jenes

texts.en:
Jenes O. is a 38 year old business lady dealing in mobile phone accessories and repair in Mwembe Tayari, Mombasa. She is married to Evans O., who supplements her income. They have been blessed with three children. Jenes has been in this business for the last ten years and it has been a success.

This is Jenes' first loan from KADET. She plans to use the money to purchase more mobile phone accessories. With the anticipated profit she hopes to open up another business and 
to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase more mobile phone accessories

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 59 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 28, 26 and 18. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making "puto" (rice cakes) and other delicacies for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

Carmelita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her family’s house.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred M. N. is twenty-seven years old, married to a casual laborer and has one child aged three years old whom he hopes to give a good education to the university level. He describes himself as very hardworking, self-motivated and optimistic.

Wilfred’s business, the AMR shop, is located in a busy market in a residential area called Mukuru Kwa Njenga. Wilfred is served by the Kitengela Branch. He has been selling general items in his shop which include cooking fat, cigarettes, detergents, kerosene and other things. He has been in business for eight months now. He says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge he has is that there are many other people in the area with the same kind of business, so customer loyalty is difficult to maintain. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well.

Wilfred is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to buy more general items which include cooking fat, detergent, flour, etc. to grow his business and be able to cater to all his customers' needs. He hopes to enlarge his shop to a supermarket. He also hopes that some day he will be able to provide employment to the local community, acquire a van and purchase land for building a supermarket.

loans.use: To buy more products such as cooking fat, detergents, flour, kerosene, etc.

loans.name: Ichinhorloo

texts.en:
Ichinhorloo N. lives with her family in Hovd, a western province in Mongolia. There are six people in the family: one daughter, two sons and three grandchildren. One son is a herder in the countryside and another son gets a disability allowance. Her daughter sells fruit.

Ichinhorloo started a grocery store in 2003 in the Han-Ord market, and since 2005 she has operated a grocery kiosk in the Erdeneburen soum [district]. She is an experienced business woman whose goal is to expand her business into a big grocery store. Ichinhorloo is requesting 500,000 MNT to purchase more inventory for her grocery shop. She aspires to a good life.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for her grocery shop

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther R. is a lady who is married and a mother to two children. She is a poultry farmer who raises chickens and later sells them at a profit to hotels in places like Embu, Nairobi, and areas around Thika. She has been in this business for eight years earning a monthly profit of 15,000 KES.

Esther was introduced to KADET by a friend. She has applied for her first loan which she will use to buy more chickens and help her husband to pay school fees for the children. She hopes to earn enough so that she can sell chickens in the areas around where she lives.

Esther aspires to have her children live a comfortable life with better schooling as well. She believes she is sincere and strong-willed enough to achieve her goals.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Kaniz Muhammad Aslam's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz M. A. is married to M. A. who is sixty years old and has run a plumbing business for the past twenty years. She is the mother of four children, three sons and a daughter. Her eldest son works in a factory for a monthly wage, while the remaining two manufacture leather jackets. Her daughter is a school teacher. They all work to contribute to their family finances. The family members are residents of Kasur which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and is famous for its leather industry.

Kaniz herself runs a small canteen in a local school where she sells food such as French fries, kababas (made of potatoes) and samosas to the students. She does this work to share the family’s financial burden with her husband.

Kaniz has applied for a fourth loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for her husband’s business. During previous loan cycles she has proved herself as a responsible person who has never missed a single meeting and paid her installments in time. With the loan, her husband will buy plumbing supplies such as taps and water pipes in bulk to sell through his plumbing shop. The bulk supplies will enable him to increase sales and income as well. Kaniz is hopeful that her husband will make a good profit by investing the loan in his business.

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Kaniz.

loans.use: To buy plumbing supplies (taps and water pipes) to sell

loans.name: Tereso

texts.en:
Tereso V. is 35 years old, married and has three children aged thirteen, nine and one. He is from the town of Talibon in Bohol province on the Visayas islands. Tereso is a fisherman who uses his fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. He is working hard because he wants to achieve his dream of having his children finish college someday.

Tereso joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. He is requesting a loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay the tuition fees for his children.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Narmandah

texts.en:
Narmandah J. is a 38-year-old woman who lives in Huvsgul province in northern Mongolia with her husband and two sons. Her husband is a carpenter and builds wooden furniture. One of her sons attends college while the other is in elementary school.

In 2003 Narmandah completed her schooling in hairdressing and began work. Today she rents a seat at a salon called “Youth.” Narmandah says, “My dream is to have my own workspace and expand my business even more so I can provide a good education for my children.” She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her salon business

loans.name: Lucresia

texts.en:
Lucresia L. is 40 years old, married and has three children aged eleven, six and three years old. She is from the town of Talibon in the province of Bohol on the Visayas islands. Lucresia runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Soft drinks are one of her best sellers. Her neighbors buy cases of soft drinks from her especially for special occasions.

Lucresia joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lucresia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marion

texts.en:
Marion M. is thirty-two years old and married. She describes herself as hardworking, business-minded, wise and honest. Her husband is employed in a flour mill, and they have four children aged between fourteen and seven years old whom they hope to give a good education up to the university level.

Marion’s business is located in a busy market in a residential area called Mukuru Kwa Njenga and is well known by the name Marion Cereals. Marion is served by the Kitengela Branch. She sells beans, maize, green grams (mung beans), rice and other cereals. She has been in business for the last one and half years now. She says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge she faces is that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, so it is difficult to maintain customer loyalty. High prices for her products also reduce the number of potential customers who could consume her products. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.

Marion is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more cereals and beans to grow her business and be able to cater to all her customers' needs. She hopes to have a big business in the future and even own her own home.

loans.use: To buy maize, beans, sorghum, millet and green grams

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie P. is 51 years old, married and has five adult-aged children. He is from the village of Barangay Munguia within the municipality of Dupax del Norte, a part of Nueva Vizcaya province on the Luzon islands. Julie is a farmer who grows and harvests rice to sell. He has been in business for over twenty years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2009 Julie joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Julie successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Julie is requesting a new loan, his fourth from ASKI, of 22,000 PHP that will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora A., from the town of Talibon, is 55 years old. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a specialized retail store selling spices and vegetables such as squash, carrots, and onions to the community. She hopes for her store to grow and wishes to acquire more vegetables to sell.

Leonora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Havings repaid her previous loan from CEVI, Leonora is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase more products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her store.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Freda

texts.en:
Freda M., from the village of Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya, is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Freda owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over nine years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Freda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mukhtayar

texts.en:
Mukhtayar belongs to a small city called Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry in Pakistan. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family in the area of Kot haleem khan. 

She is 35 years old and married to G. M.. She has three daughters and one son. All of her children are getting their education except the youngest one, who is just 5 years old and has not started attending school yet. 

Her husband is involved in a rent-a-bike business. He also has a mobile-phone shop where he sells used phone sets to his customers. He is a very responsible person in nature. He is the only breadwinner of his family so this status forces him to move forward and gives his business the right direction. He re-invests the profits in his business to earn more profit.  

Mukhtayar is a very supportive and caring lady. As her husband gets busy in his businesses, she takes care of the house and children, so her children grow up with good manners and discipline.
  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s businesses. With the loan amount, her husband will buy another motorbike for his rent-a-bike business and will buy used mobile-phone sets for his mobile-phone selling business. 
 
This loan investment will help him serve more clients and earn a better income. 

Mukhtayar is hopeful that her husband has a good experience with these businesses and that he will definitely improve his business conditions with the loan investment. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike for a rent-a-bike business and used mobile phone sets for a mobile-phone shop

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M. is from the town of Talibon. She is 32 years old and married. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda P. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 34 years old. Luzviminda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 40,000 every harvesting season.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita M. is from the town of Talibon. She is 42 years old. Lolita is married and has 7 children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making "puto" (rice cakes) and other delicacies for sale. Lolita also makes bread and dreams of having her own bakeshop someday.

Lolita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Villamor

texts.en:
Villamor D. V. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 54 years old. Villamor is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Villamor owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Villamor has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2009, Villamor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Villamor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Villamor is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Villamor from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita D. T. is from the town of Talibon. She is married and has 2 adult children. She sells spare parts for a living. Her husband, who is an engine mechanic, also helps with their business. Teresita says they have been involved in this kind of business for almost 20 years now. She is thankful to have a source of income because it helps sustain their household. She hopes to serve more customers.

Teresita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional spare parts to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional spare parts to sell

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto A. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 48 years old. Roberto is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Roberto owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Roberto has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 40,000 during harvest season. Roberto said that his earnings in the activities help him a lot in supporting the educational needs of his children.

In 2009, Roberto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roberto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Roberto is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase manure and pesticides. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Roberto from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ulziihuu

texts.en:
Ulziihuu C. is 54 years old and a widow who lives with her two daughters in a their 'ger', a traditional nomadic housing tent in Hovd province of Mongolia. Her older daughter works as a nurse in a local hospital while her younger daughter helps out with Ulziihuu's business. She operates a clothes sewing business where she makes a variety of 'deel's, or traditional Mongolian coats to order in a stall at a local market. She has been engaged this business for 15 years with help of her daughter. 

Her business has been very successful and has gained a wide customer base. Ulziihuu is a very hard-working woman and she is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and finishing materials

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John K. K. is thirty-eight years old. He is widowed. He has four children aged between eighteen years old and ten years old whom he takes care of. His business is located at a busy market in a residential area called Mukuru Kwa Njenga. However, John is served by the Kitengela Branch. 

He has been selling charcoal to the local people for the last one and half years now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the fact that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as his so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. Rainy seasons also slow down the business since there is usually low supply of charcoal. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well.

 He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more charcoal to grow his business and meet his customers' demand. He hopes to become a leading supplier of charcoal in the area and even open other outlets within the area. He also plans to diversify into kerosene supply. He describes himself as hard-working, determined and focused.

loans.use: Charcoal

loans.name: Tujikwamue Kiburugwa Group

texts.en:
Habiba S. is in her early forties and is married with two children. Habiba has been running a general store and a cosmetics shop since 2004. The grocery store is open daily between 6 am and 9 pm and earns Habiba a good monthly profit.

This will be Habiba's 10th loan with Tujijenge Tanzanania. The earlier loans were used for expanding the business as well as increasing her stock. All of these loans have since been repaid. With her 10th loan, Habiba once again aims to increase her stock of goods, both for the grocery store as well as the cosmetics shop. Habiba's dream is to one day own several grocery stores around the city.

Habiba will share this loan with her loan group Tujikwamue Kiburugwa, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Habiba can be seen in the back row, to the far left.

loans.use: Increase stock of goods

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida L. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 48 years old. Leonida is widowed. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of of her raised animals.

In 2007, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 50 years old. Letecia is married and has a 29-year-old child. She is a seaweed farmer. She plants and gathers seaweed with the help of her husband, who is also a fisherman. She also helps sell her husband's catch together with the seaweed that they have harvested. She has been involved in seaweed farming for more than 10 years now. 

Letecia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Letecia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Flordelis

texts.en:
Flordelis R. is from the town of Talibon. Her business is a sari-sari store. She sells various kinds of products like soft drinks, shampoo, sugar and many others items. According to her, she has been running the store for more than four years now. It is the main source of income her family has and she hopes it will grow more. She hopes to acquire more kinds of products to serve her neighbors.

Flordelis joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordelis is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jiminiano

texts.en:
Jiminiano M. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. He is 51 years old. Jiminiano is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Jiminiano owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Jiminiano has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jiminiano joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jiminiano has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase medication for his livestock. Jiminiano is requesting a new loan of 38,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed & other supplies. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Jiminiano from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Alain

texts.en:
Alain P. is from the village of Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 36 years old. Alain is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Alain owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Alain has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Alain joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alain is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Alain from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Munguia, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Rosaleo

texts.en:
Rosaleo C. is from the town of Talibon. He is 39 years old. Rosaleo is married and has 4 children. His eldest child is 18 years old and the youngest is 12. To make a living, Rosaleo owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. 

Rosaleo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosaleo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rosaleo is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy men’s clothing for resale

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn P. is from the town of Talibon. She is 19 years old. Jovelyn is married and has a 9-month-old baby. She buys empty shells while her husband is a fisherman. She cleans the empty shells and makes accessories and displays items in their community. She also helps sell her husband's catch and makes dried fish.

Jovelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase empty shells and repair their fishing boat. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase empty shells and repair their fishing boat

loans.name: Kasanje Twegate-Lugazi Group

texts.en:
54-year-old Immaculate M. is married and a mother of six. She belongs to the Kasanje Twegate-Lugazi Group. By operating a grocery store for the last thirty years in Kasanje-Lugazi, Immaculate has been able to put food on her family’s table as well as pay for her children’s education.

The grocery store in which she mostly sells vegetables was started with savings from a farm that Immaculate still operates, though it’s now secondary to her main enterprise. In a month she makes 100,000 UGX in profits. With this loan Immaculate is looking at the prospect of buying more vegetables to sell. Immaculate attributes her progress to hard work and determination.

loans.use: The purchase of more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 65 years old. Catalina is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Catalina owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes  from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Catalina also hopes to acquire piglets to raise. She says it would really help to have an extra source of income.

Catalina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catalina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and piglets to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and piglets to raise

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene T. is from the town of Talibon. She is 28 years old. Irene is married and has three children aged 8, 5 and 2. To make a living, Irene owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling bamboo products in the local community. She also raises pigs and chickens and hopes to acquire more livestock to raise.

Irene joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Irene is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase bamboo, piglets and chickens. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase bamboos, piglets, and chickens

loans.name: Furkat

texts.ru: Муродов Фуркат проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Более 12 лет занимается животноводством. Откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Furkat M. lives in Hamadoni. He is 36 years old, married, and has four children. He has a high school education. He has been working in animal husbandry for more than twelve years. He fattens and sells cattle. He is taking out a loan to buy more cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy W. N. is twenty-eight years old and married. Her husband is a carpenter and they have two children aged nine years old and two years old whom they hope to give a good education to the university level. 

Her business is located at a busy market in a residential area called Mukuru Kwa Njenga. Lucy is served by the Kitengela Branch. She has been selling assorted items which include hair weaves, slippers and even other items used in the house. She has been in this business for the last two years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the fact that there are many other people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers so customers are not loyal as they are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more hair weaves and other general items to grow her business and later own a salon or a wholesale shop. She has a dream of providing employment to other people in the community. She describes herself as hard-working, ambitious, independent and reliable.

loans.use: Hair weaves, slippers etc.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem lives in the small city of Punjab called Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry in Pakistan. She is 26 years old, married as a teenager to B. A. and has given birth to three children: two sons and a daughter. All of them are enrolled in school and are getting their education. 
Her husband makes and sells chikhs (a kind of curtain made of bamboo wood used as cover from the heat). He has been doing this work for the last 15 years and operates his business from his home. Now this business is well known among people of every city and they buy them to decorate their homes because it gives a nice look to the rooms. He not only makes simple chikhs but also makes embroidered chikhs as well. He gets orders from different shops in the market and provides them the finished goods on time to earn an income. 

Naseem herself does her sewing business to support her family financially. She mainly works for her neighboring customers and supplements the income for the family. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy bamboo woods, thick thread and beads in large quantities to make chikhs to fulfill the orders of his customers.  Naseem is hopeful that the fulfillment of orders will earn her husband a huge profit and as a result, her family will be able to improve its living standard. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes it will be a profitable experience for her family. 

Note: In the picture, the lady who is holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hand is Naseem.

loans.use: To buy items for making & selling chikhs

loans.name: Arnulfo

texts.en:
Arnulfo T. is from the town of Talibon. He is married and has children. He owns a sari-sari (general) store. He sells different kinds of products like vinegar, sugar, and oil. He is happy to share that he was able to buy a motorcycle. He uses it to transport people around his community and it helps their family income.

Arnulfo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arnulfo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Arnulfo is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.ru: Хушвахтов Бахром проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 33 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Бахром занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. В этой области уже 4 года. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Bahrom K. lives in Hamadoni. He is 33 years old, married, and has three children. His wife is a housewife. Bahrom works in animal husbandry. He raises cattle at home. He basically fattens and sells cattle. He has been doing this for four years. He is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Irshaad's Group

texts.en:
Irshaad comes from a small city of Punjab called Kasur, famous in Pakistan for its leather industry. She lives in a three-room brick house with her family in the area of Basti Laal Shah. She is married to S. A. and has given birth to three daughters and three sons. Only three of them could manage to get education till fifth standard. They had to leave their education due to the poor financial conditions of Irshaad and her husband. 

Irshaad’s husband operates a decorative embroidery business. He collects orders from different boutiques and cloth shops and provides them finished goods to earn an income for his family. Irshaad, her three sons and her eldest daughter also do embroidery to support S. A. in completing the orders on time. 

Irshaad has applied for a loan for her husband’s decorative embroidery business. With the loan amount her husband will buy embroidery items such as beads, colored thread and cloth in bulk quantity and make more embroidered dresses to fulfill large orders on time.  Irshaad is hopeful that her husband will successfully uplift his business with this loan investment. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application to any MFI.

loans.use: To buy embroidery supplies in bulk quantity for embroidery business

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity A. is currently in the business of selling 'simsim' (sesame seeds), peas, beans and onions  and is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell.  Charity is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a doctor. She has five children and four of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a small farm.

loans.use: Stock fish to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene W. W. is twenty-two years old and married. Her husband is a driver and they have three children aged eight years, five years and three years old whom they hope to give a good education to the university level.
