Milagros desea brindar mantenimiento a sus computadoras para que estas puedan seguir operativas y su servicio siga teniendo buena calidad, para poder realizar su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar porprimera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Milagros es una mujer bastante activa y entregada a su familia, ella desea seguir trabajando para sacar adelante a su familia. Los vecinos del lugar le consideran una mujer tranquila y responsable.
texts.en:
Milagros is a 30-year old mother who lives with her husband and children in the Pueblo Nuevo sector of the district of Buenos Aires.  This is an agricultural zone, which primarily produces cacao and organic bananas.  It is in the Morropón district of the Piura region of the country, which is more than three hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region.

Two years ago, she installed an Internet café business in her home.  Her business is utilized by area youngsters and students primarily to do their homework and for entertainment.  Over this period of time, her business has become known and she now has regular customers.  She uses the income she generates through this activity to help her husband support the family financially.

Milagros wishes to maintain her computers so they continue to operate properly and she can provide a high level of service.  To meet her goal, she requested a loan of 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Milagros is a very active woman, who is dedicated to her family.  She wants to continue to work to help them get ahead.  Her neighbors consider her a calm and responsible woman.

loans.use: To maintain her computers so she can improve her Internet cafe service.

loans.name: Isidro

texts.es:
Isidro es un padre de familia de 36 años de edad que vive junto a su familia en el sector Laynas del distrito de La Matanza, provincia de Morropón, se encuentra ubicada a mas de tres horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica desde hace mas de tres años a brindar servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros en una mototaxi (vehículo motorizado consistente en una motocicleta que lleva anexada una cabina en la cual se ofrece servicio de transporte). El brinda su servicio durante todo el día dentro de su distrito y en las principales zonas aledañas. Estos vehículos son bastante solicitados por la población de la zona ya que constituyen una alternativa rápida y barata para transportarse.

Lamentablemente, el continuo uso brindado a su unidad móvil y el mal estado de los caminos de la zona han hecho que su mototaxi empiece a sufrir algunas fallas que requieren de urgente reparación para garantizar su correcto funcionamiento, por este motivo ha decidido solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 700 nuevos soles.

Isidro es una persona bastante responsable y trabajadora. Su mayor anhelo es ver a su familia gozar de una mejor calidad de vida, los pobladores de la zona le consideran alguien de confianza. Anteriormente ha tenido un crédito con Edpyme Alternativa y ha demostrado responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas
texts.en:
Isidro is a 36-year old father who lives with his family in the Laynas sector of the La Matanza district in the province of Morropón.  This area is located more than three and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region.

For more than three years, he has dedicated himself to providing transportation services for passengers with a mototaxi (a motorized vehicle that consists of a motorcycle with a passenger cabin attached, used to provide transportation for riders).  He provides his service all day within his district, as well as in neighboring areas.  These vehicles are in high demand, as it is a quick and cheap mode of transportation for residents of the area.

Unfortunately, continuous use and the bad state of the area’s roads have resulted in his vehicle having some mechanical problems.  These require urgent repairs in order to continue functioning reliably.  For this reason, he has turned to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 700 Peruvian soles.

Isidro is a responsible and hard-working person.  His greatest desire is to see his family enjoy a better quality of life.  Area residents consider him a trustworthy person.  He has previously had a loan with Edpyme Alternativa, and he demonstrated his responsible nature from the moment he assumed his payments.

loans.use: To pay for repairs and maintenance expenses for his mototaxi.

loans.name: Neva

texts.en:
Neva A. lives in the village of Sepac Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old, married and makes a living by selling items people use daily such as canned goods, sardines, noodles, sugar, candies, shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She has been in business for more than one year and earns about 8,000 PHP a month. 

Earlier this year, Neva joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for her first loan, for 20,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia S. is from the village of Matugas Alto, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old, married, and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting, harvesting, and selling rice. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Delia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used as additional capital for her business. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Delia’s fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Katty Alexandra

texts.es:
En la ciudadela La California de la ciudad de Portoviejo, conocida como la Ciudad de los Reales Tamarindos se reúne cada quince días, el Banco Comunal Su Bankito.

Para la señora Katty este es el segundo ciclo en el Banco Comunal y al igual que sus compañeras esta muy contenta y espera seguir por muchos ciclos mas. Tiene 28 años de edad y esta casada hace 5 años, de esta linda relación tiene dos hermosos pequeñitos uno de 4 años y una linda niña de 11 m eses de edad que son su más valioso tesoro. Su esposo es cerrajero y estudia licenciatura en música en la Universidad.

Ella es un ama de casa que para ayudarse con los gastos de su familia decidió dedicarse a la venta de zapatos el cual lo hace con un sistema de venta puerta a puerta, trabaja todos los días de dos a tres horas por día,  dice que se le dificulta un poco porque sus hijos están pequeños y a veces no tiene con quien dejarlos en el momento de ir a realizar sus recorridos, pero igual ella  siempre busca la forma de visitar a sus clientes. También realiza trabajos de belleza ya que tiene un titulo de artesana.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar zapatos ya que tiene varios encargos y sabanas ya que también quiere entra en ese negocio.
 
Sus sueños son terminar su carrera universitaria y tener un almacén.
texts.en:
Every 15 days, in the citadel La California in the city of Portoviejo which is known as the city of the Reales Tamarindos, the “Su Bankito” communal bank meets.

Mrs. Katty is in her second rotation with the communal bank and, like her colleagues, she is very happy and hopes to continue for many more rotations.  She is 28 years old and has been married for 5 years.  She has two beautiful children, a 4 year old boy and a pretty little 11 month old girl, who are her most valuable treasures.  Her husband is a locksmith and is studying for his degree in music at the university.

She is a homemaker who, in order to help with the family expenses, decided to sell shoes.  She works via door-to-door sales for 3 hours every day.  She says it is a little difficult because her children are small and sometimes she doesn’t have anybody to leave them with when she needs to do her routes, but, she always finds a way to see her customers.  She also works as a beautician as she has her diploma in this area.  

This loan will be used to buy shoes and bed sheets, as she has various orders that need filling and she would like to sell sheets as part of her business as well.

Her dream is to finish her university studies and own a store.

loans.use: To buy shoes and bed sheets.

loans.name: Marly Ruth Elizabeth

texts.es:
En la ciudadela La California de la ciudad de Portoviejo, conocida como la Ciudad de los Reales Tamarindos se reúne cada quince días, el Banco Comunal Su Bankito.

Aquí conversamos con la señora Marly ella tiene 54 años de edad y está soltera, en su juventud tuvo un hijo que a pesar que ya es mayor de edad siempre ha sido su compañía, ella es profesora de una escuela fiscal de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Es su segundo ciclo en el Banco Comunal y se desempeña como Presidenta del mismo, función que cumple con mucha responsabilidad.

Se dedica a la venta de productos de Yanbal (artículos de belleza, perfumería y accesorios ),  también vende joyas de Romanel,  su sistema de venta es por catalogo, ofrece sus productos y después de esto realiza los pedidos a la empresa, deja a crédito sus productos y cobra cada quince días. Dice que a veces aprovecha las ofertas para comprar mas barato y después las vende al precio normal lo que le deja unas ganancias extras.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar mas de sus productos ya que es fin de mes y tiene que cancelar lo que ha pedido.

Su sueño es tener su propia distribuidora.
texts.en:
In the La California neighborhood in the city of Portoviejo, known as the city of the “Royal Tamarind Trees”, the community bank, “Su Bankito”, meets every two weeks.

Here we are speaking with Marly. She is 54 years old and single. In her youth, she had a child who is now of legal age. She works as a public school teacher in the city of Portoviejo. This is her second cycle in the community bank and she is president of the group, a position she holds with great responsibility.

She sells Yanbal products (beauty products, perfumes and accessories), she also sells Romanel jewelry. She sells her products through a catalog system. She presents her products and then she fills the orders, sells the products on credit and collects payments every two weeks. She says that sometimes she takes advantage of sales in order to buy things cheaply and then later she sells them at regular price, so that she can make extra profit.

She will use this loan to buy more of her products; now that it is the end of the month and she has to cancel what she ordered. Her dream is to have her own distributor.

loans.use: To buy Yanbal cosmetics and Romanel jewelry

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda S. is from the village of Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old, married, and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as sugar, coffee, milk, noodles, sardines, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Yolanda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Yolanda’s third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase sardines, sugar, milk, cofee and noodles for sale

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina P. is from the village of Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,600 PHP a month.

In 2009, Gina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase equipment to improve the business. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her services. This will be Gina’s second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials needed to provide her services

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en:
Celsa B. is from the village of Sagrada, Tambulig, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 55 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Celsa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting, harvesting, and selling rice. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Celsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Celsa’s sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

location.town: Sagrada Familia, Tambulig, Zamboanga del sur

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma A. is from the village of Dioyo, in Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Gemma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector. The main source of income for the business comes from selling home furniture like beds, sala sets and cabinets to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Gemma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials needed to make the products she sells. This will be Gemma’s second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline B. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old. Jacqueline is married and has 3 adult children. Jacqueline owns & operates a pedicab transport service. Jacqueline has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jacqueline joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Jacqueline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. 

Jacqueline is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Jacqueline from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
Batchuluun D. is 53 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province in Mongolia. His oldest daughter lives on her own, his middle daughter is a student and his young son attends a local high school. He and his family have been living at their current home address for the past 28 years. 

He used to operate a public transportation service in his town but, due to his wife's bad health condition, he sold his car that he used in his transportation business in order to cure his wife's disease. He currently works as a bus driver to supplement his family's income. In addition, he purchases machinery spare parts at wholesale prices to sell for profits. 

He used his previous loan profits to pay for his wife's medical treatment. Now he wants to improve his business so he needs to have more funding.  Batchuluun is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase spare parts at wholesale prices from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to resell

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza T. is from the village of San Jose, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 31 years old. Liza is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Liza operates a retail store where she sells products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, noodles and canned goods in the local community. Liza is just starting this business.

In 2007, Liza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. The previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Liza is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be invested in expanding the business. This will be Liza's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business by purchasing additional goods.

location.town: San Jose, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Meryline

texts.en:
"Industrious" is a characteristic that best describes Meryline A., a married 42-year-old. She and her partner were blessed with two children, a 14-year-old high school student and an 11-year-old 5th grader. The couple is full of hopes and dreams, especially for their children. As much as possible, education is their priority for their children, and also to provide their basic needs for a better life. 

Meryline joined Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI) - a partner micro-finance institution of KIVA - in the Philippines in 2006. The couple agreed on this decision to join the program. Her previous loans were utilized by financing a retail store. Today the store is their primary source of income aside from the income of her husband from his work. 

She is glad that she was able to help her husband with their financial needs without leaving her household chores, and was able to finance a new project from her earnings, which is doormat weaving. Now she is applying for a loan of 13,500 PHP to use as additional capital for buying grocery products to sell, such as canned goods, sacks of rice and sugar, cases of soft drinks, liquors, cigarettes, bath and detergent soaps, toothpaste, shampoo and assorted noodles. 

She is hopeful that with this new capital she can start saving in preparation for her children's future schooling and for renovation of their house. She is also planning to establish a new grocery store to increase her profit. She hopes that ASHI and KIVA will support her all the way in achieving her goals in life.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery products to sell

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan C. is a 35-year-old single mother who lives with her father and her three children in Hovd province in Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest two children, aged 13 and 7, both attend the local secondary school while her youngest son is in kindergarten. 

Her father is retired and he operates a taxi service using his own car that he recently purchased with a pension loan. Bayasgalan operates a small cafe at a rented space in the local market. She has been engaged in this business for the past six years and has built a stable operation. 

She hopes to expand her business and says, "All I want is to establish a new cafe for my daughter. Construction of the cafe building is started and in the process of pouring concrete." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to use for the construction of her new cafe.

loans.use: Construction of her new cafe

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa M. is from the village of San Jose, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 26 years old. Elsa is married and has three young children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a retail store where she sells clothing and dry goods.  Elsa has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2600 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Elsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be invested in expanding the business. This will be Elsa's fourth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business by purchasing materials.

location.town: San Jose, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Idalia

texts.es:
Idalia García y Eduardo Tapias, su esposo (que aparece en la fotografia y trabaja como empleado en una empresa de Barranquilla) es una pareja que vino con sus 4 hijos desde San Juan Nepomuceno, cuando se radicaron  muy cerca de Barranquilla. En su pueblo natal Idalia  tenia un negocio de vender prendas de oro, y al partir de allí, porque se volvió   difícil la convivencia pacífica, abandonó su negocio y trajo solo $100.000 COP, pero como ya tenía  la experiencia de negocios, no abandonó la convicción de iniciarlo en la nueva población; así fue que invirtió en mercancía y repartió entre varios clientes que le recomendaron  a los que semanalmente visitaba para recoger el dinero producto de sus ventas, que volvía a invertir  y con este trabajo lograba generar  utilidades para ayudar a sostener su hogar. 

Como esto no le alcanzaba para responder a su clientela, se empleó de doméstica es una casa por días   y fue así como reunió dinero para comprar constantemente; cuando obtuvo su capital , aún quedaba mal en responder a los pedidos,  por eso una amiga le recomendó buscar un crédito con la  Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y ella accedió,  hizo algunos cursos administrativos, pero a pesar de que le aprobaron su crédito, su esposo como no tenía experiencia en este tipo de financiamiento, le recomendó no retirar el dinero de su cuenta y devolverlo, ella así lo hizo mientras continuaba trabajando con mucha dificultad lo que la obligó a regresar a esta organización,  sin decirle a su cónyuge  y ahora se siente muy contenta porque su negocio ha logrado crecer; antes tenía su mercancía metida en un tanque,  hoy tiene cuatro vitrinas muy bien surtidas en un sector comercial y donde todo el que pasa le compra porque es muy concurrido. Ahora su esposo quien aparece con ella en la fotografía se siente orgulloso de ella y la acompaña en todas las decisiones emprendedoras de Idalia, pues ha logrado demostrar su potencial de crecimiento y gran capacidad de multiplicar su dinero. 

En la actualidad solicita su credikiva para ponerle cielo raso a su negocio que con el apoyo de la fundación,  logró adecuar un local y separar la zona familiar de la productiva y ahora necesita enchaparla para que se vea más vistoso y todos sus clientes no quieran Salir de él de lo cómodo que se encuentran. Idalia dice que nada hubiera sido posible sin la ayuda de Dios, y que a él le pide cumplir su sueño de tener un almacén. Su más grande desafío fue cuando su hija sufrió un accidente y ella la ayudó a salir adelante descapitalizándose un poco, aquí recuerda como la Fundación siempre en estos casos le ha tendido la mano, por eso no se cambia a ninguna institución.
texts.en:
Idalia G. and Eduardo Tapias, her husband (who appears in the photo and works in another business in Barranquilla) are a couple who, between the ages of 24 and 34 years old, came with their four children from San Juan Nepomuceno to a place very near Barranquilla. In their hometown of Idalia, they were selling items made of gold; because it became difficult to live together peacefully, they abandoned their business and brought only $100,000 COP, but since they already had business experience, they did not abandon the will to begin it again in a new place; therefore, they invested in merchandise and distributed it among various customers who recommended them, and they visited them weekly to collect the money from sales, which they again invested, and in this way generated profits to help them afford their home. 

As this was not enough for serving their customers, they began working out of their home by day, and this was how they earned money for constant purchases, when they had the capital, although it was still not enough to fill all the orders. Because of this a friend recommended they seek a loan with Kiva partner Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, and Idalia agreed. She took some management classes, but when the Fundacion approved her loan, her husband, who did not have experience with this kind of financing, suggested that she not take the money out of her account and that she return it. Idalia did so, while continuing to work with great difficulty, which drove her to return to this organization without telling her husband, and now she is very pleased because her business has grown. Before, she had her merchandise displayed in a tank; now she has four well stocked display cases in a commercial area where everyone who passes buys because its very popular. Now, her husband, who is in the picture with her, is proud of her and assists her in all the business decisions. She has demonstrated her ability to grow and multiply her money. 

Now she is requesting her loan to put in a ceiling, and, with the help of the Fundacion, adapt the place to separate the family area from the business area. She needs to cover it so it will look nice and so her customers will never want to leave the comfort they find themselves in.  Idalia says that none of this would have been possible without God's help, and she asks Him to help her realize her dream and have a warehouse.  Her biggest challenge was when her daughter had an accident, and she helped her be more successful by selling off a bit, and she remembers how in these sorts of cases the Fundacion always lent her a hand, and because of this she will never go to any other organization.

loans.use: Remodel store

loans.name: Evaluz

texts.en:
Evaluz V. and her husband dreamed of having their own house in the future and to live a simple but comfortable life. However, her husband passed away and that dream was left to Evaluz to accomplish. At age 56 and a widow, she did not lose hope that she could still fulfill the dream of having their own house. Though life became tough for her, she never gave up. Instead she worked hard in order to perform her responsibilities as both father and mother of their three children. 

To have access to capital to start a small business, she joined Ahon sa HIrap, Inc.- a partner micro-finance institution of KIVA in the Philippines - in the year 2006. During those years she experienced hardship but she was so determined that she stayed active in her membership. She is one of the very good members of ASHI and serves as a model to her group and to the center. Her business is doing well and her profit helps in providing the daily needs of her family. 

Now she is applying for another loan of 14,000 PHP to use as additional capital for her store. She will buy more grocery products, canned goods, bath and detergent soaps, liquors, cigarettes, rice, sugar, cooking ingredients, shampoos, assorted candies and snack foods. She will also buy assorted toys in preparation for the Christmas season. 

She was able to send her children up to high school and is still dreaming of sending them to college someday. She hopes that with this additional capital she can earn more and save for the schooling of her children and hopefully start building their own house. She is optimistic that she will reach all her dreams with the help and support of ASHI and KIVA, and of course with the blessing from our Creator.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery products to resell

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en:
Tsetsegmaa G. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and four school aged children in Hovd province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a rented yard. Her four children all attend the local school while her husband works in the construction field. 

Tsetsegmaa operates a fruit retail business at the "Han-Ord" local market. She purchases fruits from her sibling and sells them to people for a profit. She has been engaged this business for two years and has gained much experience as well as a strong customer base. Tsetsegmaa is a very modest woman and is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fruit at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit

loans.name: Tundan - 2 Group

texts.en:
Analiza B. is from the village of Boundary Sapang Dalaga Mismais Occidental. She is 33 years old. Analiza is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Tundan - 2.

Analiza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Analiza owns and operates a store selling fruit such as lanzones, marang, and bananas in the local community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Analiza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Analiza's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional agricultural products to sell

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa T. is applying for additional Php 14,000.00 pesos to accommodate the increasing number of customers ordering  Ready to Wear (RTW) dresses and clothes. This is her second loan with KIVA. She is so grateful to serve all her customers on time and that is why she is applying for another capital loan to supply the demand. She is happy that as a member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. – a partner microfinance institution of KIVA in the Philippines that she can easily access this capital. She is also a good and active member of the institution. 

She will use the loan to buy new RTW products and expand her market to other municipalities. She will buy RTW products in bulk and at a discounted price to her customers on an installment basis. Her customers will pay her at a set retail price for a period of one month in two installments. Her profit from this business supports her husband with their daily needs especially with the school expenses of their 5 children. Her children are all studying, with 4 in college and 1 in high school. She is hoping that ASHI and KIVA will continue to support her with her plans and dreams.

loans.use: to buy ready to wear clothes

loans.name: Tundan 1 Group

texts.en:
Maricel P. is from the village of Tru-cut Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old. Maricel is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is tundan 1.

Maricel is married and has two young children. To make a living, Maricel owns and operates a store selling fruits like lanzones, marang, bananas, rambutan and mangusteen in the local community. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Maricel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Maricel's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural products to sell

loans.name: Marita

texts.en:
Living along the shore of Laguna de Bay in the Philippines is the family of Marita S.. She is 35 years old, married to a fisherman and blessed with 4 children. The family depends only on fishing as their source of income. Her husband does the fishing but he has to borrow fishing gear from their relatives or neighbors for a certain percentage of the catch. For this reason the income is not sufficient for the family. 

It was in 2009 that Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI) a microfinance institution and partner of KIVA in the Philippines, opened its program in their community.  Marita immediately grabbed the opportunity to join the program. Full of hopes and motivation that she could buy fishing gear for her husband, she looked for 4 interested friends to form a loan group. Her first and second loan were utilized in buying fishing nets and the loan she is applying today, worth Php 15,000.00 pesos, will be used to purchase a “Banca” (a canoe made of fiver glass) so that her husband will no longer borrow from others. He will be glad to have his own banca because it does not only increase their income but it allows him to go fishing anytime at his convenience. She is so excited because since she joined ASHI their life became much easier than before. The couple can now meet the needs of the family and send their children to school. The couples are glad there are institution like ASHI and KIVA that provides financial assistance with social response to poor but deserving families like theirs.

loans.use: to buy a "banca" , a boat/canoe made of fiber glass

loans.name: Lovely Jean

texts.en: In 2009 Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner microfinance institution of KIVA in the Philippines, started its operation in the home town where Lovely Jean T. Lived.  She and her husband decided to join the program to have access to capital and were convince by the principles and methodology of the program. Her first loan was used as additional capital for her small convenient store and the second was utilized by her husband as capital for his junkshop business. The two businesses, which the couple manage, give adequate profit to finance their basic necessities and send their 2 children to a reputable school. They were able to buy additional appliances and accordingly their life became much easier than before. Again, they want to apply for a loan of Php 15,000.00 pesos to buy additional grocery items, rice, sugar, soft drinks, canned goods, bath and laundry soaps, shampoo, candies, snacks and other items. The proceeds of this additional capital will surely help the couple to sustain the growing needs of their family and Lovely Jean can start saving for the achievement of their dreams. The couple desires to provide their children a quality education, comfortable house and attend their daily needs. They also wish to sustain their businesses and create employment among their neighbors, friends and relatives. She hopes and pray to GOD that ASHI and KIVA will support her all the way in achieving their dreams.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products; rice, sugar, soft drinks, canned goods, bath and laundry soaps, shampoo, candies and snack foods

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene M., 59 years old, is a joyful but hardworking mother of 6 children. Because of poverty she was compelled to stop schooling and enter the life of marriage at an early age. During the early stage of their marriage their income was only sufficient for their daily consumptions and that’s why her 3 eldest children never reached college. However, she works hard and awith patience and perseverance she was able to send her children to college. Her other 3 youngest children were able to graduate from college and ASHI was part of this success. Because of her loans she was able to finance her business and earn a living. As a member she did her best to become active and performs her duties and responsibilities with dignity. 

She is again applying for a loan of Php 20,000.00 pesos to buy additional fruits, vegetables, meat, fish and kitchen utensils for her food vending project and grocery products for her store. Her profit from this additional capital will be used to support the school expenses of her grandchildren. She will also save for the construction of a much more convenient store and food stall for her customers. Irene also dreams of renovating their house with the help of her husband and children. She really admires the service that ASHI and KIVA provide with poor but worthy families who are full of hopes and dreams but limited by bureaucracy. According to her, the opportunity of becoming a member of ASHI and KIVA really is a privilege that she will always cherished.

loans.use: to buy meat, fish, fruits and vegetables products

loans.name: Castorina

texts.es:
Creaciones Casto, es la idea más genial que se le ha ocurrido a Castorina Vélez Hernández, una mujer de 53 años de edad con dos hijos en las edades de 13 y 19 años, que no hace más que trabajar, trabajar y trabajar para sacar a su familia adelante. Desde que tenía 16 años ayudó a su mamá en el arte,  que  de ella heredó,  y que hoy, es la fuente de su ingreso más importante: la confección de ropa en la línea deportiva.  Con su madre desarrolló su potencial emprendedor y aprendió a ser independiente y esto es la base del éxito que hoy tiene como confeccionista.
Castorina ha recibido tres créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y con su credikiva comprará telas, e insumos, para responder a los contratos que tiene de hacer uniformes escolares y ropa deportiva. En sus tres años de ser cliente de esta organización, ha logrado cambios sustanciales como el de tener un  capital de trabajo con el que antes no contaba, entusiasmarse permanentemente para conseguir clientes, y esto se refleja en el aumento del volumen de sus ventas. Su sueño más adelante es ampliar su negocio, tener un local propio y darse a conocer a nivel local por sus diseños. Su desafío constante es sostenerse en el mercado con innovación y buen servicio, además de despertarse cada día y dar gracias a Dios por haber podido continuar trabajando a pesar de un accidente que casi logra descapitalizarla, pero esto es hoy un problema ya superado y ahora está en la búsqueda permanente de  nuevos  horizontes , que le ayuden a tener un futuro exitoso para su familia.
texts.en:
Creaciones Casto is the wonderful idea that Castorina Vélez Hernández had. She is a 53 year old woman with two children who are 13 and 19 years old, and she does nothing other than work, work, and work in order to provide for her family. Since she was 16 years old, she helped her mother with the art, which she inherited from her, and so now it's the most important source of income for her: making sports clothes. She developed her entrepreneurial ability with her mother and learned to be independent, and this is foundation for the success she now has as a clothing-maker.

Castorina has received three loans from Kiva partner Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo, and with her CrediKiva loan, she will buy fabrics and supplies to fill orders that she has for school uniforms and sports clothes. In her three years of being a customer of this organization, she has made substantial changes, such as having working capital, which she didn't have before and always being excited to get new customers. This shows in her increased sales. Her biggest dream is to grow her business, have her own store, and become known at the local level for her designs. Her constant challenge is to survive in the marketplace through innovation and good service, plus, she wakes up every day and thanks God for allowing her to continue working after an accident that almost bankrupted her, but this is already a problem that she has overcome, and now she is always looking for new horizons that will help her create a successful future for her family.

loans.use: Purchase fabric and supplies to fill orders and make school uniforms and sports clothing.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia S. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 42 years old. Alicia is separated from her spouse and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a store selling rice and corn grits, canned goods, noodles, dried fish and bagoong in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Alicia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be invested in expanding the business. This will be Alicia's sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business by purchasing addtitional products

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Ma. Nolita

texts.en: Ma. Nolita A., 42 years old, is married with two children and is new member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc.(ASHI) – a partner microfinance institution of KIVA here in the Philippines. She joined ASHI last year to meet new friends and have additional capital for her small convenient store, their primary source of income. She wishes to increase her stocks of grocery items to meet the demand of her customers so she has applied for Php 5,000.00 pesos loan. Also, she wanted to increase her earnings so that she can help her husband in their financial needs and buy construction material for their house and store. More importantly she wanted her children to finish college and have stable jobs in the future. That is why she desire to improve her earnings and saveings. It will be the fulfillment of her dream if both children will complete a degree in college. She wishes to extend her thanks to ASHI and KIVA for giving her the opportunity to become a member.

loans.use: to buy grocery products

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
Evelyn Casinas is from the town of Banga. She is 31 years old. Evelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years.

Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Evelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine V., from the village of Bitibut Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental, is 36 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Geraldine owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as rice and corn grits, dried fish, canned goods, pancit, milo, milk, coffee, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Geraldine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC that was used both to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her second loan of 7000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Geraldine plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products such as rice and corn grits to sell

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa R., 51 years old and mother of 3 children, just joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner microfinance institution of KIVA here in the Philippines this year. When she heard of ASHI she instantly topped the list of those who were interested to join the program. She is deeply encouraged by the principle of the institution and the financial assistance it provided to people with nothing to put up for collateral or a guarantee. After days of rigid seminars, she became a full-pledge member.

Now Marissa is applying for a loan of PPH 5,000 to fund her buying and selling of fish and vegetables project. She dreams of having a stable business in the future to help her husband and family. Her earnings from this venture will be use to expand her business and support her family in their needs. She is hoping and praying that ASHI and KIVA will help her achieve her dreams for her 2 youngest sons to pursue their choice of career.

loans.use: To buy fish and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A. joins Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) (a partner microfinance institution of KIVA in the Philippines) to increase capital for her convenience store. 

Before joining, she already has the experience of running a store. As of now her current business is doing well, but because she is planning to put together a grocery store to support the increasing number of residents in hercommunity, she joined ASHI to have access on financial assistance. She wants to expand her business and buy more stocks to accommodate the needs of her customers, the reason why she is applying for a PHP 5,000 pesos loan as additional capital.  She also wants to support her nephew in his schooling and provide the needs of her family as well.

Joining ASHI and its partner KIVA she believe is the answer to her dream that’s why she is motivated to fulfill her duties and responsibilities with utmost sincerity.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products for her store

loans.name: Chito

texts.en:
Chito D. C. is from the town of Banga. He is 41 years old. Chito is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a farm. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Chito works hard to improve his harvest in order to earn more. 

Chito joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and his living situation. He has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Chito is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en:
Aiza G. has a sari-sari (convenience) store and a rice and corn farm. From these, she is able to generate income for her family. She has three children. He eldest child is eight years old; her youngest is only one year old.  

She wishes to improve their living conditions, so she has applied to CEVI for a loan of Php 5,000. With the loan, she will buy additional merchandise to sell and farm supplies. She likes CEVI because of its insurance services. 

She hopes someday to have a bigger store so that she will be able to support the education of her children and give them a brighter future.

loans.use: To buy additional store merchandise and farm supplies

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace S. is from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She has seven children that she supports through planting rice. She grew up farming and is very knowledgeable about growing crops. Her dream for her children is for them to finish their studies. She wants all of them to secure employment so that they will be able to support their children when they have their own families.

She has applied for a loan of Php 9,000 in order to improve their living conditions. She will use it to buy farm fertilizers and other supplies. She likes CEVI because of its insurance services and good customer service.

loans.use: To buy farm fertilizers and other supplies

loans.name: Hector

texts.en:
Hector T. is from the village of Centro 2. He is 41 years old, married, and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Hector owns and operates a manufacturing business, making furniture. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Hector has been engaged in his business for over 21 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Hector joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hector has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Hector is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Hector from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida A., 44 years old, is a very industrious and diligent mother. She has four children, of which the eldest is 17 years old and a freshman college student, followed by a 13 year old, 10 year old, and the youngest at six years old. Her husband, a fisherman, does the fishing while she either sells the catch at the market, or goes around and sells it to people in their community or in a nearby locality. Her husband is always longing for more fishing gear that he can use to increase the volume of fish he catches, and increase profits as well. He is also planning to put up a fishpond with the next loan. They decided to join Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. – a partner MFI of KIVA -- in the Philippines to gain access to capital that they can used to buy their needed fishing gear and planned fishpond. She is applying for 5,000 PHP to finance her husband's plan to buy fishing gear and capital for fish vending. They believe that ASHI and KIVA can help them achieved their goal as couple, which is to provide a better living and education for their children.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear and capital for fish vending

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley M. is interested in improving the size of her harvest. Normally, she only gets enough for her family, and now, what she would like to do is to maximize her farm so that she is able to provide more for the needs of her family. 

At the moment, she would like to ask for a loan of 5,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She thinks that getting a loan will be helpful to her to support the growth of her farm. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds. She is hopeful that through this, she will be able to increase her yield.

loans.use: Farm supplies, like fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Pepita

texts.en:
Pepita P. is engaged in multiple businesses. She owns a motor and a fishing trap. She sells fish and at the same time manages a small farm. She plants and harvests rice and corn crops from her farm. From these, she is able to generate enough income for her family.

She wants to grow her business more. She would like to ask for a loan of 5,000 PHP. She will use this loan to purchase farm inputs and invest in her other businesses. She is very optimistic that her loan will really help her grow her business profit. In that way, she will be able to provide more for the needs of her family.

loans.use: Farm inputs, and to invest in her other businesses

loans.name: Maria Luz

texts.en:
Maria Luz L., 28, is a rice farmer. She started tilling a farm five years ago. From growing rice, she is able to raise funds for her family. She has three children, the eldest is seven years old, while her youngest is only three years old. 

She would like to ask for a loan of 5,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to grow her harvest. The income from her business will benefit the entire family. She is hoping to save enough money for the education of her children.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie L., 25 years old, is a sari-sari storeowner. She is also a farmer.  She is doing these activities to be able to purchase items to fulfill the needs of their family. She has one son. She is saving money for her to support for the needs of her son.

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell and purchase farm supplies. In that way, she will be able to offer her customers with more products with variety and supply her farm of needed inputs. She likes the CEVI services because she is also covered by micro-insurance benefits.

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise to resell and farm supplies.

loans.name: Ma. Beverlita

texts.en:
Ma. Beverlita A., 46 years old is engaged in a rice farming business. In addition to the farming, she also owns a sari-sari store. The loan, which she will receive from Community Economic Ventures Inc., will be used towards buying additional merchandise to resell. It will also be utilized to buy farm materials like seeds and fertilizers.
 
She said that she likes the CEVI program because, aside from the loan, she has learned a lot from biblical reflection. She is also proud that she has an insurance coverage with her membership at CEVI. She likes the way CEVI processes all the loans for borrowers like her.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Rupa Kumari

texts.en:
This is 34 year-old Rupa Kumari K.. She is married and has 3 children, aged 13,12 and 8. In 2005, she established her fruits shop business. Working 7 days a week, 11 hours a day, she supports her family. She wants this loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Rupa Kumari plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates: BPW Partner Page 

Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To increase inventory of store.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila L. manages a small rice farm. This is where she has spent her entire life. The income, which she and her husband are able to generate, helps a lot in providing for the daily needs of her family. 

Mila has children and she has dreams for them. She has been working so hard to be able to provide for their needs. For her it’s a big challenge, especially when her kids will ask for something about school. Now, she would like to apply for a loan of PHP 5,000. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers. In that way, she will be able to increase her harvest and her income.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Aini

texts.en:
This is 26 year-old Aini S.. She is married and has no children. In 2009, she established her general store business. Working 7 days a week, 10 hours a day, she supports her family. She wants this loan from Patan BPW in order to increase the inventory of her store. In the future, Aini plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support.  

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
BPW Partner Page     

Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: Towards increasing the inventory of her store.

loans.name: Ma. Cecelia

texts.en:
Ma. Cecelia L. 41 is a farmer. She plants and harvests rice for a living. She started earning her livelihood two years ago and she hopes to have a sustainable business to help support her family. 

She would like to apply a loan of PhP 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers. In this way, she will be able to continue earning an income to cover the education of their son.

loans.use: farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Julie Ann

texts.en:
Julie Ann O. is from the town of Sta. Josafe, Agusan Del Sur. She is a farmer. She has entirely spent her life growing vegetables and rice to earn an income for her family. She is married and has one daughter; she hopes that someday she will be able to send her to school.

She would like to apply for a loan of PhP 5,000. She will use the loan to buy seeds and farm materials. She hopes this loan will be able to sustain her business and family.

loans.use: buying seeds and farm materials

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A., 40 years old, owns a small parcel of land that she farms. Almost every important memory she has in her life relates to her farm. The land, which she is tilling right now, is very important to her. What she really dreams of is to make it productive to support their needs.

Victoria would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 which she will use to buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer. She hopes that by focusing on the needs of her farm, it will be very easy for her to achieve the desired harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita R., 51, is a rice grower and has operated her business for quite a long time now. She envisions her children having a proper education and this is why she works harder to earn more. She owns a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field and hopes to have a huge income to uplift her family’s living conditions.

Lolita joined CEVI for the purpose of having a business of her own and to sustain her family’s basic needs. This loan will be used to supply her farm needs like fertilizer, pesticides, and other supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm needs like fertilizer, pesticides, and other supplies

loans.name: Razia Allah Wasaiya's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in the small Pakistani city of Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry. She is a 27-year-old housewife who spends most of her time staying at home and doing her household tasks. She is married to A. W. who runs a small restaurant in the market. In his restaurant he sells Punjabi foods such as naan chanay (made with chickpeas and served with bread) and daal chawal (made with rice and lentils and served with pickle). He has been in this business for the past seven years, during which time he has earned an advantage in the form of a healthy profit and a good customer base. From the profits of his restaurant business, he is able to manage his family's financial expenses.
Razia is a very supportive lady by nature. She supports her husband by preparing food for the restaurant so that he can better provide service to his customers. Razia has four sons and a daughter. Her eldest son works in a factory and the next son operates a tea stall in the market. Her remaining children are enrolled in school and receiving an education.
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her son’s tea-stall business. With the loan amount, her son will buy items such as tea, sugar and milk in bulk. These bulk purchases will help him to serve more customers and increase his income. Razia is a regular Asasah loan user and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit record and never missed a meeting.
Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Razia.

loans.use: To buy required items for tea-stall business

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer L., 33 years old, has been a farmer for quite a long time now. She is seeking funds to help her buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds. She is working very hard to be able to help buy the basic needs of her family.

She needs a loan of PhP 9,000. She will use the loan to improve her harvest.  In that way, she will be able to send her children to school. She said she likes the services of CEVI. She likes it because she has also micro-insurance coverage.

loans.use: purchasing farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en: Liezl C., 39, is married and has seven children. She is a farmer. She wants her children to finish their studies so she ventured into this business. She is engaged in rice farming. She joined CEVI because it helps her augment her financial capability and she was able to buy fertilizers for her rice field. The loan will be used to buy her farm materials like seeds, fertilizers, etc.

loans.use: farm materials like seeds, fertilizers, etc.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a thirty-six-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda; He is married with four children and lives in a rented house. John’s dream is to see his family living in their own house, educating his children and boosting his wife’s business. He has been in the construction business for seventeen years, and his business has withstood the test of time, in that he started with the initial capital of two hundred thousand but he has so far realized more than two million shillings from the business. 

John needs this loan to buy a motorcycle for a transport business so as to realize increased sources of income for his family.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia lives in a small city of Punjab called Kasur. Kasur city is famous in Pakistan for its leather industry. She is a 25-year-old lady who is married to A., and she has no children yet. Her husband is involved in the business of fruit-selling and has been doing this business for the last seven years. He is the only breadwinner of the family and so he has to work hard for the betterment of his family so they get the basic necessities of life and never suffer for want of little things.  

That’s why Nazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy seasonal fruit in bulk quantity and improve his sales. He has a plan to start a fruit shop in the market where he can display a variety of fruits to people and improve his client base. He is hopeful that he will be able to do so with the loan profit.  

Nazia is also hopeful that her husband will make good use of this money and successfully achieve his plan for the future. She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her 1st loan application. She hopes it will be a profitable experience for her. 

Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Nazia.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit in bulk quantity for fruit-selling business

loans.name: Melma

texts.en:
Melma D. owns a small hectare of rice farm. The purpose why she grows rice is for family consumption and livelihood. She sells most of her harvest to her neighbors and because of that, she is able to earn enough income for her family. One thing she would like to do in her life is to send her children to school. With her current business, which is a rice farm, it’s a challenge for her to fulfill her plan.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 7,000. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to grow her harvest. She is also interested in some other business opportunities so that she will be able to supplement their income.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy high-quality seed and mineral fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is from the town of Sta. Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She is 46 years old, married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is 23 years old and the youngest is 9. She is involved in farming and has been planting and harvesting rice for more than 15 years now. Her husband, who is also a farmer, also does his best to keep their farm productive. Teresita wishes for her family to have better living conditions. She says that she believes everything is attainable if you work hard for it. 

Teresita joined CEVI to avail of its financial service. She has repaid a previous loan, which she said helped her farm a lot. She still needs financial support to be able to buy farm inputs and materials for the farm. She has applied for a loan of PHP 7,000, which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other inputs.

loans.use: Towards buying seeds, fertilizers and other inputs.

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad is married to S. A. and lives in a small city in Punjab, called Kasur, which is famous for its leather industry in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms in the area named Laari-ada and lives in it with her family. 

Irshad is a very talented lady. She owns & operates a decorative embroidery business at her home. Her clientele base are her neighbors and she receives regular orders from them to earn good profit on her business. She is very good at her art and knows different embroidery techniques, which makes her unique among other business women in the community. She crafts beautiful embroidery designs on clothes to attract more customers towards her work.  
Her husband is involved in a bread-making & selling business. He owns a tandoor (a kind of oven made with mud and wood-burning fire) in the community. He sells his bread in 5 PKRs which has become a standard amount in every city. He has been serving the people of his community for the past 6 years. He supplies breads to different restaurants as well and earns a good profit.
