Sakina has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s bread-making & selling business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy flour and wood in bulk quantities, which will enable him to make more bread and to increase the sales as well.

loans.use: To buy required items for bread making & selling business.

loans.name: Shaban

texts.en: Shaban is a 32-year-old married man with three children aged 10, 12, and 6 years. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in a semi-permanent house and is the breadwinner of the family .Shaban’s family dream is to educate his children to attain better qualifications. He has been in the butcher business for seven years. He started as a hired employee but now he has his own butcher shop. His challenge is the rainy season when customer numbers are low. He adds that he hopes to have a bigger butcher shop in the near future. Shaban needs this loan to buy more cows to sell as beef in his butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy cows to sells as beef in his butcher shop

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita F., 50 years old, is a mother of 3 children. She is a hardworking mother and a very active member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.- a partner MFI of KIVA in the Philippines since 2001. Managing a store has been her main source of income since joining the program. From this business she was able to generate a profit and support her family for their financial needs. Again, she is applying for a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy additional stock for her store. She will use the income from this additional capital to improve her store. She is planning to develop her store to accommodate more inventory and to add convenience for her buyers and future customers. Her future business plan is to buy a jeepney, or motorcycle, that they can use for deliveries. For her family, she dreams of her children finishing a degree and securing stable jobs. She is thankful to KIVA lenders for supporting her goals in life.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery products.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en: Frank is a young man of 25 who is married with three children and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He lives in a rented house and his family dream is to educate his children. Frank has been operating a retail shop for the past five years in addition to his pasturing. In his retail shop, Frank sells soft drinks, sugar, rice, cooking oil, soap and other domestic items. His business dream is to have his retail shop turned into a wholesale shop. Frank intends to use this loan to buy a fridge to cool the soft drinks and purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell in his retail shop.

loans.use: To buy a fridge, sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Nasuuru

texts.en: Nasuuru is a 25-year-old married man with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a semi-permanent house in the village although he is renting in town and his family dream is to have his home and family in town to access better services. Nasuuru has a butcher shop and has been in the business for 10 years. When his business started, he sold only goat meat but now he can afford beef although the rainy season is still a hindrance to the business as customers hardly buy beef in that period. His business dream is to have a number of butcher shops in different areas. Nasuuru needs this loan to buy more cattle to sell as beef at his butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy cattle to sell as beef at his butcher shop.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is a 23-year-old man, looking after his siblings. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a permanent house and lives with six family members. His dream is to educate his siblings to have better qualifications. Richard is a motorcycle rider and has been in the business for four years now. He has the challenges of irregular customers and fluctuating fuel prices. He needs this loan to buy an improved model of motorcycle that is appropriate for the region of his transport business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for a transport business

loans.name: Toirchon

texts.ru: Абдурасулов Тоирчон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 28 лет. Холост. Образование среднее. Занимается перевозкой людей, то есть предоставляет услугу, такси. Он в основном развозит людей по маршруту Хамадони - Душанбе, Душанбе - Хамадони. В этой области уже 4 года. Кредит берет для приобретения новой автомашины.
texts.en: Toirchon A. lives in the Hamadoni district.  He is 28 years old, single.  He has a secondary education.  Toirchon is involved in passenger transportation, i.e. he provides taxi service.  He primarily transports people on the Hamadoni-Dushanbe, Dushanbe-Hamadoni route.  Toirchon has been in this field for 4 years.  He is requesting this loan in order to purchase a new car.

loans.use: Purchase of a new car

loans.name: Mable

texts.en: Mable is a 44-year-old single woman with four children living in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. As a single mother, all the family responsibility for ensuring the welfare and education of the children is on her head. Her dream is to have all the children complete tertiary institutions. She owns a boutique and for six years she has seen it grow tremendously from initial capital of 1,500,000 shillings to 5,000,000. There is a risk in transporting goods from the capital city to Fort Portal as theft is rampant in the city. Mable needs this loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: He wants to complete his stocks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy items for his wedding and arrange the wedding party

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To progress pashton's husband business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To complete his necessities of the shop.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
43-year-old Lina is from the town of Sta. Josefa in Agusan Del Sur. She is a farmer. Together, with her husband, she plants and harvests rice crops on their land. She says the farm is very helpful to her family because it helps provide for their needs. She hopes to increase her yield so she can also earn better. Lina has children who go to school and she works hard to sustain their education. For her, education is one of the best things she could give to them.

Lina currently needs inputs for her rice farm. She needs seeds, fertilizers and other farming materials. She is applying for a loan of PHP 8,000. This loan will truly help Lina in her farming.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita L. joined Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner MFI of KIVA in the Philippines in 2007. She is now 50 years old, married and has 2 children. Their primary source of income is production of “Taho”, a snack food made of processed soya beans with jelly and syrup and ice cream sticks. They have vendors that roam around the community and nearby localities to sell their products on a commission basis. It’s been their source of living and was able to help other people to earn a living. With her income she was able to send her eldest daughter to college and finish a degree and support the youngest in his schooling. She is applying for a PHP 25,000 loan to buy more raw products for her business. This will help to increase production and generate more profits. She is thankful to ASHI and KIVA lenders for financial support and hopes that the two institutions will continue until she reaches her business goals.

loans.use: To buy raw products for "taho" and ice cream stick production.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B., 48 years old, is from Sta. Josefa. She is married and has four children. Her eldest child is 22 years old while the youngest is 12. Josephine has a piggery and a sari-sari store. She raises pigs for breeding. Sold at her store are various products such as vinegar, sugar and detergent soap. She says the store helps provide for her family's daily needs while she earns from the pigs on a monthly basis. Josephine works hard to sustain her family and especially to provide her children with an education.

Josephine applied for a loan of PHP5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a KIVA partner in the Philippines. She will use to loan to buy feed for the pigs and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To purchase feed and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase a new sewing table

loans.name: Myanzi Mixed Group-Mityana

texts.en:
Twenty thousand shillings weekly profits is what 37-year-old Roset N.’s 15-year-old retail shop business in Myanzi-Mityana generates. Barring the many operational-cost challenges she has been facing, she says she probably would be making more. For a woman whose business pedigree can be traced to a hawking (selling door-to-door or on foot) business, it’s been hard work all this while, with a set objective of firmly establishing and consolidating her modest gains. 

She also operates a modest produce-selling business. This mother of three's business is thriving, though not at the level she likes it too. The root of her problems is that lack of financial muscle to expand or to buy more stock. It was with a friend’s encouragement that she began this business. 

With this loan, Roset is anticipating making bulk purchases of more retail stock. Items like sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, beans, etc., are high on her shopping list. She belongs to the Myanzi Mixed Group.

loans.use: The purchase of sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, beans, etc.

loans.name: Terere Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
34-year-old N. Kulusumu belongs to Terere Development group-Mukono. She runs a pharmacy, which she started after she finished school. Her business has been in existence for 10 years. She also runs a commercial motorcycle business that helps increase her income. 

Hard work and determination have been her trump card. She makes 130,000 shillings a week. With this loan, this mother of two says she is going to buy more drugs for her pharmacy.

loans.use: To purchase drugs for her pharmacy

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy firewood and flour

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand and improve his shop

loans.name: Nishaat Akhter's Group

texts.en:
Nishaat Akhter (who we see here with her hand raised) lives in a Pakistani city called Vehari, which is famous for its farm products. She is very talented, and works both as a housewife and a seamstress, giving her time freely to both activities. Her daily routine consists of waking up very early, doing her household chores, and then sewing clothes for her customers. She makes a good income from her work, which allows her to pay her utility bills.  She is very skilled at what she does, and her clients perfer her work to that done by her competitors. 
 
Her husband, S. A., is an entrepreneur who makes a living by trading in fertilizer and seeds. His customers are farmers, and he earns a good profit by supplying them with items they need. He has been in this line of work for nine yeas and has a strong reputation among his customers for high quality and timely delivery of orders. 

Nishaat, who leads the five-member loan group we see here, has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand husband’s business. The couple will use its portion of this loan to buy seeds and fertilizer in bulk to sell to his customers. Nishaat is very confident that her husband will be able to successfully increase his income by making positive use of this loan.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds in bulk

loans.name: Felina

texts.en: Felena Bredan is 62 years old an a  member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. – a microfinance partner of Kiva in the Philippines. Felena’s dream is to have a nice, comfortable house with rooms she can rent out to boarders. While still young, she decided to remain single so that she could support her family. She uses the profits she earns from renting rooms to help her brothers, sisters and other member of her family. She also saves some money to pay her health expenses. She is applying for a loan for 25,000 PHP to use to buy materials and pay workers to expand and renovate her house. Her goal is to make her home more inviting to boarders, especially students who go to nearby schools. She hopes and prays that ASHI and KIVA will help her reach her dreams in life.

loans.use: To improve and expand her boarding house

loans.name: Namataba Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
In Namataba-Mukono, there is a sand quarry that is well known for employing energetic youth who work hard everyday to make ends meet. Out of curiosity, I took it upon myself to visit this riveting place. There is a semblance of beehive activity as young people go about their work. 

M. Muhammed, who started the quarry three years ago, is a good humored and easily approachable lad who has one child. He belongs to the Namataba Development  group. He traces his business roots to selling maize or corn, which he says was of paramount importance in getting him on his feet. He makes 80,000 shillings a week. Muhammed also ekes further profits from selling fresh food. 

Paying the employees of his quarry has been an experience that has often dampened and played havoc with the smooth operations of his business. This loan will help him pay his employees.

loans.use: To pay salaries of the manpower he employs

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith G. is a 55-year-old widow who has three grown children, the oldest of whom is 36. Judith earns a living by farming and running a small store. She plants and harvests rice, and her sari-sari (or variety) store contains different products that people in her community need every day. Although her children are all grown now, she still wants to help provide for their household needs. 

Judith is hoping to increase her income, and would like to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm and additional merchandise to sell in her store. To pay for these items, she has applied for a loan of 5,000 PHP from CEVI.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and items to sell in her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To repair his taxi and purchase a new engine for it

loans.name: Razia Abdul Sattar's Group

texts.en:
Razia is married to A. S. who runs a grocery shop in his local area. She lives with her family in the mid-sized Pakistani city of Vehari, known for its agricultural industry. She has been living in this city since her marriage many years ago.
Razia is a seamstress and sews clothes for customers in her neighborhood in order to share the financial burden with her husband. She learned her sewing skill from her mother and started working independently after her marriage. Her mother was unable to provide Razia with an education but she gave her a skill that will benefit her at every step of life. Razia is also a very good housewife. Alongside her business she deals with her responsibilities as a mother and wife very well.
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries for his grocery shop to increase his sales and income. Razia hopes that this investment will bring a good profit to add to her family's income and that they will be able to enjoy a better standard of living.
Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Razia.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Gabil

texts.ru:
Gabil P. 32 qoda. On ne jenat. Gabil yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Lachin, seychas projivayet v Absheron regione. 

On uje 8 let kak  rabotayet myasnikom. Etomu biznessu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo dedushki. Seychas Gabil nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit myaso dlya pereprodaji.
texts.en: Gabil P. is 32 years old. He is single. Gabil is an Internally Displaced Person; he is a refugee from Lachin, currently living in the Absheron Region. He has been working as a butcher for eight years. He learned this trade from his grandfather. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy meat for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing meat for resale

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie is a 42-year-old married woman from Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. The eldest among her 6 children is 23 years old. Virgie is a rice farmer, just like her husband. Both of them spend most of their time keeping their farm productive. Virgie also makes delicacies that she sells around their neighborhood. She says it helps in their daily needs and she hopes to have a sari-sari store where she can sell more kinds of products.

Virgie is applying for a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI. She will use it to buy farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell. She is hopeful that this loan will help her business immensely.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Bazirengedde Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
“Men have sight--Women have insight”- This is an adage firmly embedded in 33-year-old K. Grace. K. belongs to Bazirengedde group. Because she has been able to solve deeply entrenched financial adversity on her own with no support, she now has a deeper perspective and understanding of how to handle a crisis situation in business. Notwithstanding the relatively short period of time she has had her food snack and soft drink restaurant business, she has given a good account of herself as a business woman. 

Lady luck has shone on Grace’s married life. She and her husband have three highly spirited kids who she says take after both of them in many ways. 

Running this business has struck a deep chord with clients who flock to her restaurant. Like her name, K. Grace is truly gracious. She began her business journey selling charcoal and firewood. Grace credits her sister with giving her the inspiration to begin this business. With this loan, she says she is going to buy more furniture for her restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase furniture for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To repair her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Kiwamirembe Women's Group-Mukono

texts.en:
It has been 10 years and this 48-year-old woman is still counting her blessings for the success of her hardware business in Kigombya-Mukono. Welcome to the world of one diligent woman, M. Margaret, a lady with the courage of her convictions. Her business has been instrumental in uplifting not only her financial well being but also her family’s status. 

Margaret is part of a group of borrowers called Kiwamirembe. Margaret is happily married and has nine children. Margaret works hard, and she makes 100,000 shillings a week. With this loan, she will purchase more hardware parts for resell at her shop so she can increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase more hardware parts

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita A. is a 33-year-old married woman living in Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. She has 4 children and 3 of them go to school. Perlita earns through farming and retailing. She tills a rice farm near their house. She also sells various kinds of products at her sari-sari store. Perlita works hard to provide for her family. She says she does everything to keep her family healthy, especially her children.

Perlita needs additional merchandise to sell and farm inputs for her rice field. She applied for a loan of PHP 7,000 that she will use to sustain her business.

loans.use: Purchase farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Faakhra's Group

texts.en:
Faakhra is the resident of a small housing colony named 77-15L, located in the mid-sized city, Vehari, famous for its agriculture industry in Pakistan. 
She is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and manage the household chores and to take care of her family. 
Her husband operates a small medicine shop in the community. As his community is not based on well-educated families, thats why they had to face problems when they become ill due to the lack of medical clinics in the nearby areas. 
But the problem became solved when M. A. opened a medical shop five years ago and people started getting good advantage by buying medicines from him to timely cure the pains and bad health conditions. Now they have become his regular customers and give him good profit on sales. 
 
Faakhra has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s medical shop. With the loan amount, her husband will buy the medicines in bulk quantity to help him to serve his customers by providing them with more medicines.  
Faakhra is very hopeful that this investment will bring positive change to her husband’s business and the household income will grow. 
Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Faakhra”.

loans.use: To buy medicines in bulk quantity for medicine selling business.

loans.name: Tukole Namanyi Group-Mukono

texts.en: N.'s training as a nurse has prepared her well for her job at her drug store. 30-year-old N. Annet of Tukole Namanyi group is unlike the unqualified people who operate drug pharmacies without medical training. Honest is a precept that she says has brought forth success in her work. The testament to that is the 200,000 shillings she earns on a weekly basis. Her business is now five years old. Her diverse client base includes the low, the middle, and the upper class people around the Nabuti neighborhood. With this loan she wants to purchase more drugs for resell at her pharmacy.

loans.use: To purchase drugs for her pharmacy

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cotton, cloth and quilt sewing needles.

loans.name: Never Give Up Group-Mukono

texts.en: K. Bruno, 40, belongs to Never give up group-Mukono. He is a happily married father of two. Self-interest drove him to begin his commercial motorcycle business in Nabuti four years ago. Before that, he was running a beauty salon. His weekly profits now total up to 60,000 UGX. Bruno wants to buy another motorcycle with his loan and his savings from previous loans.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle

loans.name: Misbah Ejaz Hussain's Group

texts.en:
Misbah is a resident of the mid-sized Pakistani city of Vehari, which is famous for its agricultural industry. She operates an embroidery business from her home. She is excellent at her work and receives regular orders. Her finished products have a good market value. Due to her good embroidery skills, Misbah not only receives orders from her neighbors but from clothes shops as well. Her earnings allow her to share the financial burden with her husband.
Misbah's husband is E. H. and he is involved in a rent-a-bike business. His locality is a few kilometers from the city and there are no other transport facilities so people come to him to rent a bike. He charges rent on an hourly basis. His business brings him good earnings, and these help him to manage the financial aspect of his family.
Misbah has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s rent-a-bike business. With the loan, he will purchase another motorbike to improve his business. Misbah is hopeful that by purchasing another bike to add to her husband’s business, he will be able to improve his business and double his income.
Note: In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Misbah.

loans.use: To buy another bike for her husband's rent-a-bike business

loans.name: Rwensinga Twimukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
Operating a grocery store business has really improved her living conditions, having gotten herself involved in the farming business in the past. Twenty years ago B. Jane, age 48, of the Rwensinga Twimukye group, changed her business into a food selling enterprise. She sells products like beans, millet flour, peas and maize flour in the Ndorogi trading centre, Ibanda. She earns approximately $89 a month.
 
A married mother of two adopted children, Jane has worked hard, knowing that her responsibilities are cut out for her. She has been able to take care of her family's requirements, including meeting the school fees for the children and other necessities. 

Her drawback is having a small stock of products to sell, so this loan will enable her to expand the business through buying more goods for her customers to buy. This will increase her sales revenue and allow her to live a more sustaining life. She is looking forward to business expansion and building her own store.

loans.use: purchase of more stock of food stuffs for resale

loans.name: Rukundo Group

texts.fr:
Yvette N. est une femme commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite au Quartier Kamenge en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce des habits pour toutes catégories depuis 10 ans. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année de l’école primaire. Son mari, Benoit Twagirayezu est lui aussi un commerçant. Elle arrive au 8e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 3enfants qui sont âgés de  5ans, 3ans et 1 an. Ils n’ont pas encore commence l’école. 
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité des habits  à vendre dans l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice. Elle espère avoir un grand capital dans l’avenir qui lui permettra de faire un grand business. Elle espère en plus, qu’avec des économies générées de ce business, elle parviendra à construire sa propre maison et assurer l’éducation de ses enfants jusqu’ils terminent leurs études avec grand succès.

 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  Communautaire« Rukundo».
texts.en:
Yvette N. is a 30-year-old retailer who lives in the Kamenge district of Bujumbura. She attended primary school up to the 6th grade. She has been selling all kinds of clothes for 10 years. Her husband, Benoit Twagirayezu, is also a retailer. Yvette has three children, ages 5, 3 and 1, who do not yet go to school.
  
Yvette is currently on the 8th cycle of community credit with the Turame MFI. She is seeking credit through Kiva to increase her stocks of clothes for sale, and hopefully boost her profits. She hopes to have more capital in the future, which would enable her to run a large business. She also hopes that with the savings from her activity, she will be able to build a house and pay for her children’s tuition until they successfully complete their studies.

Yvette is a member of the Rukundo community group.

loans.use: To increase her stocks of clothes for sale, and make substantial profits

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy note books, pens and more for sale in the stationary shop

loans.name: Selly

texts.en:
Selly C. is 37 years old, married to Henry Sirimo Komen.  They have four children age fourteen years, seven years, five years and three years respectively. They live in Kapsoya an outcast of Eldoret town. Selly has dairy farm where she earn her income. She has been in this business for the past four years with an income of Kshs.30,000 per month.

Selly was introduced to KADET LTD by Credit officer.  She is applying for a loan of Kshs 25,000 with KADET LTD with which she plans to purchase two more dairy cattle for milk production. 

She hopes to operate a large scale dairy farm, so she is able to supply milk to hotels.

loans.use: To purchase two more dairy cattle

loans.name: Gulzar's Group

texts.en:
Gulzar lives with her family in an area named 77-15L, which is located in a mid-sized city Vehari, known for its agriculture industry in Pakistan. She is a house wife, stays at home and take care of her family. Her husband's name is M. H. who runs a grocery shop in the market. He offers a variety of daily use items to his customers and fulfills their requirements by selling the items they request. He started this business five years ago and his was the only shop in market, as a result of which, he earned a good daily income.

But now he is facing high competition from other grocery shops because they are offering a variety of items according to the need of the customers. It will become difficult for him to manage the financial expenses of his family if he loses his customer base. Gulzar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy the groceries in bulk to meet the requirements of his customers so he may improve his business condition. Gulzar is hopeful that with this investment in the business, her husband will be able to compete with other grocery shops and successfully retain his customers.

Note: “In the picture, the lady who is raising her hand is Gulzar”.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk quantity for grocery shop

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
This is determined and trustworthy K. Annet, who is married and has three children. She is energetic with her agricultural businesses in Nyakaina, Rukungiri. She owns a banana plantation and other agricultural farms that include cattle grazing, all of which generate income for the family. This has allowed her to earn approximately $135 on a monthly basis.

Her main drawback has been lack of funding to purchase manure and mulches for the banana plantation, and this has reduced her production and sales revenue. Therefore this loan will help her improve her yields in terms of banana production and enable her to meet the customers’ high demands and also increase her sales revenue. She will be more able to meet her family's needs in terms of tuition fees for her children, and allow them to live a more self sustaining life.

loans.use: purchase of banana plantation supplies like manure

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa L. is from the town of Banga. She is 49 years old, married and has 6 children. Her eldest is 29 years old and the youngest is 18. To make a living, Elsa owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Elsa also helps her husband at the farm when she has time, mostly with selling their harvest.

Elsa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elsa is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Beat Art And Craft Group-Jinja

texts.en: Beat Art and Craft is the name of the group that 40-year-old B. Musa belongs to. This pleasantly approachable man, who is also the father of three, has been in charge of his agricultural products sales business in Jinja market for the last twenty years. His business story goes all the way back to the time when he began selling second hand clothes. It’s with capital from this business that he started his current business. Being a go-getter in business is one sure way of achieving success. $45 is what he makes in a week. With this loan, he wants to purchase more bags of agro products to resell. He is looking at buying more maize, beans, cassava, coffee and pumpkins.

loans.use: The purchase of more maize, beans, cassava and pumpkins for resell

loans.name: Niyomwizero Group

texts.fr:
Véronique I. est une femme commerçante âgée de 37 ans qui habite la localité de Gatumba  dans la Province de Bujumbura Rural. Elle fait le commerce des produits alimentaires dans un restaurant qu’elle tient à la frontière avec le Congo(RDC) voisin depuis 10ans. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au niveau du secondaire mais n’a pas pu obtenir son diplome.Son mari est un fonctionnaire. Elle arrivait au 4e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame, mais elle intègre maintenant le crédit solidaire. 

Elle est mère de 4enfants qui sont adultes âgés de plus de 20 ans qui étudient à l’Université.
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  et varier son business en ajoutant des pagnes qu’elle compte acheter et revendre aux clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Elle a préféré demander le crédit à Turame car elle a beaucoup d’opportunités de devenir indépendante financièrement. Elle espère avoir un grand capital dans l’avenir qui lui permettra de faire un grand business. 

 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  solidaire« Niyomwizero».
texts.en:
Véronique I. is a 37 year old business woman who lives in the town of Gatumba in the province of rural Bujumbura.  For ten years, she has sold basic foodstuffs in a restaurant that she runs on the border with neighboring Congo (DRC).  She attended school through the secondary level but did not receive her diploma. Her husband is a civil servant. She is in her her fourth cycle of group loans with Turame, but now also incorporates an individual loan.

She is the mother of four adult children, each over 20 years old, who study at the university.

She is requesting this Kiva loan to increase her capital and diversify her business by adding pieces of cloth which she can buy and resell to customers and thus be able to increase her savings.  She preferred to ask for the loan from Turame because she has many opportunities to become financially independent.  She hopes to have a large stock of capital in the future, which will allow her to have a large business practice.

She is one of the members of the group "Niyomwizero."

loans.use: increasing capital and diversifying business in order to increase savings

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz F., from the town of Banga, is 47 years old, married and has two children aged 16 and 13. To make a living, Beatriz plants and harvests rice for sale and also manages a sari-sari store where she sells products such as sugar and vinegar. She works hard to manage her businesses in order to provide for her family's needs.

Beatriz joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase farm inputs and additional store merchandise. Beatriz plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs and additional store merchandise

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James K. is 35 years old. He is married and has two children, aged 4 and 7 years. They hope to give them a good education to the university level.

His business is located at a busy area in Kakamega. He sells an assortment of goods, including mobile-phone accessories like chargers and batteries. He also sells such items as watches, radios, extension cables, etc., to the local people. He has been doing this business for four years and has two employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. 

He is using his loan of 48,000 Keyan shillings to buy more mobile-phone accessories to grow his business and meet the demand from his customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He describes himself as very hardworking, determined and focused.

loans.use: Mobile accessories

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter S. is from the town of Banga. He is 42 years old and married. He has three children, who are 13, 11 and 4 years of age. 

Peter is a farmer. He plants rice, coconut trees and bananas. He and his wife sell their harvest to the market. Sometimes, they use some of their harvest for family consumption. Peter does his best to sustain his farm so he can earn better and provide for his family.

Peter joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Peter has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Peter is requesting a new loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other inputs

loans.name: Odmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Odmaa is 27 years old, married, and has one daughter who is 5 years old. Her husband, Turkhuu, who is 30, works as a taxi driver. They do not have their own land and house to live in and are staying in Turkhuu’s grandmother’s house at the moment.

She has been running a retail shoe business since 2007 and it has been doing very well since then. She buys shoes from wholesalers who bring them from China and sells them at her stall in the local market in Ulaanbaatar city. 

She is a very hardworking person. Her future plan is to expand her business and to buy a family house. The loan she is requesting will be used to increase her inventory and to buy warm winter shoes for resale.

loans.use: to increase her inventory and to buy a warm winter shoes for resale

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo L. is from the town of Banga. He is 63 years old. Rodolfo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rodolfo plants and harvests rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in farming for over 40 years.

Rodolfo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children and improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam C. is 42 years old, married and has two children aged seventeen and twelve. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Meriam runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She also helps her husband plant rice at their farm. She says their harvest is both for their own consumption and is also sold at the market.

Meriam joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and buy additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James “Juma” H. W. is forty-six years old, married and has seven children aged between six and twenty-five years old. His wife sells fish and cereals. They hope to give their children a good education to the university level. Juma describes himself as very hardworking and honest.

Although it is a restaurant, Juma’s business is well known as the Salama Hotel. It is located in a busy town centre called Kakamegaand. He serves tea, doughnuts, chicken, stew and other types of Kenyan dishes. He has been in business for fifteen years now. He says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge he has is a shortage of water. With his business, water is key, and Juma has to buy lots of water to keep the restaurant running, which in the long run is very costly and eats up most of his hard-earned profits.

Juma is using his loan of 20,000 KES to buy more cooking oil, sugar and other foodstuffs for his restaurant. He hopes to diversify to sugarcane farming and later in the future build a house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, sugar and other foodstuffs for his restaurant

loans.name: C5281 New Life Group

texts.en:
Donatha is 36 years old and married with two children who are 12 and 17 years old.  Donatha is the leader of a group called “New Life” and this group has owned a public secretariat since 2005.  The business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Donatha and her team need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, they will expand their business by buying some additional equipment such as computers, etc.  With additional computers, the number of their clients will increase; thus, the profits will allow this team to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy some additional equipment

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
Saidi is 38 years old and is married with two children who are 6 and 12 years old. Saidi is well-known in the business of selling a variety of goods such as cosmetics and plastic items like jugs, cups, baths, etc. In addition to that, he sells some other goods as the photo indicates.

Saidi is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company and, on receiving this loan, he will focus his business on the sale of foodstuffs as they are among his goods which are more frequently bought than others. If successful, He will create some other sources of income as well as creating jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Romela

texts.en:
Romela A. is 50 years old, married and has two children. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Romela has been planting and harvesting rice for more than twenty years. She says their farm helps her family a lot.

Romela and her husband also bought two motorcycles that are being used to transport people around their community. They hired two relatives as drivers, and the income from the motorcycles helps in taking care of their daily needs.

Romela joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Romela is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used for farm supplies and motorcycle maintenance. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: For farm supplies and motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Arab Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
33-year-old K. Annet, who belongs to the Arab Development Group, has been operating her pub business for the last three years in Namizi village in Central Jinja.  She began her business with only two crates of beer. 

Before that she was involved in timber sales. Over time her business has expanded, though rather minimally, as evidenced by the close to $9 she makes in a week. Modest profits, indeed, though she has been supplementing her income with sales profits from selling crops such as maize and cassava.

Annet is married and is a mother to four cheerful kids. With this loan she wants buy more alcoholic beverages for her pub.

loans.use: The purchase of more alcoholic beverages for resale

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David A. O. is thirty-six years old and married. His wife is employed, and they have three children aged between three months and seventeen years. They hope to give them a good education to the university level. David describes himself as very hardworking and honest.

David sells new clothes that include panties, vests, shirts, trousers, etc. to local people. His business is located in a busy town centre called Kakamega. He has been in business for two years now and says that this business is profitable. The major challenge David faces is that there are other people in the area doing the same kind of business, so it is difficult to maintain customer loyalty. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well.

David is using his loan of 50,000 KES to buy more clothes to meet his customers' demands. He hopes to be able to supply clothes to other retailers in bulk.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 36 years old and is married with four children who are between 6 and 15 years old.

Joyce owns a restaurant where she sells tea and some pastries. She has been in this business for about seven years and her small restaurant is open from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Joyce needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her business through increasing the size of the place where she operates her business. After getting enough space, she will also buy some additional equipment so that her customers can feel comfortable with her service.

If successful, Joyce will hopefully earn more profits which, in turn, will allow her to continue taking care of her family and save for her future.

loans.use: To increase her business space and to buy some equipment

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. is 52 years old, widowed and has two children. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Susan raises pigs for fattening and sale. She also maintains a rice field. Her children help to keep their crops healthy and the farm productive.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP that will be used to purchase feed and farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Jenie

texts.en:
Jenie C. is 32 years old, married and has two school-aged children. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Jenie raises pigs for fattening and sale.

Jenie joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jenie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase piglets

loans.name: Balitwegomba Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
46-year-old M. Juliet belongs to Balitwegomba Women’s group-Jinja. For eight years now she has been operating her second hand clothes and retail shop businesses along Kamuli road in Jinja. Juliet has been relying on her buoyant disposition to attract clients, most of whom are community members. Her involvement in this business was spawned by savings from her earlier poultry business. 

This married mother of four describes herself as fully focused and steadfast. $67 is the approximate amount of money she makes as profits per week. 

With her portion of this loan she says she is going to purchase more bales of clothes to sell and to buy retail items such as sugar, soap, maize flour, etc, for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bales of clothes to resell

loans.name: Ghulaam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Ghulaam fatima, with raised hand, lives with her family in the mid-sized city of Vehari, famous for its agriculture, in Pakistan. She is married to K. P. who has a construction supply business. He operates a shop in the market from where he deals with his customers. In order to share the financial burden with her husband, Ghulaam operates a business of sewing clothes at home. She sews for her neighbors and charges approximately 100-150 PKRs for each dress. Due to her quality work, her customers happily pay the amount without any discussion. Her earnings pay for the utilities expenses of her family. 

Ghulaam fatima has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan he will buy construction supplies such as cement, sand, and bricks and increase his income by selling through his shop. She hopes that her husband will be able to improve his business by this investment in it.

loans.use: To buy supplies for construction supply business

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en: Stanley O. K. is thirty seven years old and married. His wife is a business lady and they have two children aged fourteen and seven who they hope can have good education to the university level. His business is located in a busy town centre called Kakamega. He sells new clothes which include shirts, blouses, trousers. He has had this business for ten years. He says that his business is profitable and his major challenge is that there are other people in the area doing the same kind of business so customers are spoilt for choice. The customers' purchasing power is also low compared to bigger towns within the country. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more clothes to meet his customers' demands and hopes to expand his business and buy land from the profits. He describes himself as very hard-working and visionary.

loans.use: Clothes

loans.name: Saleema's Group

texts.en:
Saleema, with hand raised, lives in the mid-sized city of Vehari, famous for its agriculture, in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms in the area named 561-EB, a few kilometer outside the city, where she lives with her family. She has an embroidery business at home. She learned this art when she was very young from her mother and now makes good profits from it. She and her husband work hard to improve the financial condition of their family. Her husband's name is S. H. and he operates a grocery shop in the market where he sells daily-use items such as cooking oil, rice, and flour 

Saleema has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy groceries in bulk for his shop. The bulk items will help him to compete in the market and increase his sales.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk for grocery shop

loans.name: Anjeline

texts.en:
Anjeline is a married woman with a 15 year-old son. She rents a house with both electricity and water from where she has operated a dress-making business for 15 years. Sometimes her clients bring her the material and she makes the dresses for them at a fee. With the Kshs. 40000 she hopes to buy clothing and embroidery materials. Her greatest monthly expense is the purchase of the materials she uses in her business. Her major business challenge is that it takes a long time to make the dresses as she has to go to town for the embroidery part. Angeline also runs a hair salon as her other source of income

Anjeline hopes to expand her work area and employ some people to assist her in the business with the aim of creating opportunities for others. She decided to work with Yehu so as to obtain assistance with financial services and business skills.

loans.use: Buy clothing and embroidery materials

loans.name: Tweyambe Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
It was after she got apprentice training at a local institution that 38-year-old K. Oliver nurtured the idea of starting her now four-and-a-half-year-old tailoring business. She combines this business with second hand clothing sales, all in Napier market in Jinja. Oliver’s group is called Tweyambe Women’s group. 

She is happily married with three kids. Before she even thought of beginning these businesses she was more into milk selling, given that she had a cow at home. It’s a business she still operates though at a lower level. On a weekly basis her business generates her about $40. 

With her portion of this loan Oliver says she is going to purchase a new sewing machine and also buy more second hand clothing for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of a new sewing machine and also the purchase of more second hand clothing for resale

loans.name: Meche

texts.en:
Meche L. is from the town of Banga. She is 64 years old and married with four children. To make a living, Meche operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Meche also buys fish from fishermen and makes dried fish which she sells in the neighborhood.

Meche joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase farm supplies and additional fish to dry. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and additional fish to dry

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mr. S. was born in 1982 and is a resident of Kompong Chhnang province, where he constructed a workshop to operate a vehicle repairing service for a profit. He is married to Mrs. Sreysros, and they have given birth to a young child who is enrolled in the primary school. S.’s wife is a grocery seller who sells cooking ingredients, soft drinks, and some sweets to people who are their nearby villagers. 

S. said that his house is getting old and has broken often, and it has been affecting the family's living conditions. Because of this, S. decided to take out a loan to replace the broken part of his old house.

loans.use: To replace the broken part of his old house.

loans.name: Bashiran Abdul Majeed's Group

texts.en:
Bashiran A. M. is a housewife who spends her time at home doing household chores and taking care of her family. She lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari that is famous for its agricultural industry in Pakistan. Her husband’s name is A. M. whose tea stall in the market earns him income for his family. He has been in business for the past seven years. He is good at making tea and can make different and tasty-flavored teas such as green tea, milky tea, creamy tea and black tea. People of Pakistan are fond of tea. It is a Pakistani custom to serve guests a cup of tea first, then serve them food.

Bashiran has applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan her husband will buy milk, sugar and tea for his tea stall. Bashiran is hopeful that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and that he will be able to make his income double in size by increasing his clientele.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Bashiran.

loans.use: To buy milk, sugar and tea for her husband's tea stall

loans.name: Twejeko Obwavu Group-Jinja

texts.en: T. Harriet of Twejeko Obwavu group-Jinja is a 46-year-old mother of six. Her poultry business has been in existence for the last four years in Nizam-Jinja. This business was started with savings from her stationery shop, which she still owns. Profits from these two businesses come in handy in enabling her to provide basic home needs for her family. By her own account, $18 is approximately what she makes in a week. With her portion of this loan she wants to buy broiler and layer chickens.

loans.use: The purchase of broiler and layer chickens

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor O. O. is twenty-four years old and married with no children yet. His wife stays at home to perform household chores as Victor goes out to earn a living. His business is located in a busy town center called Kakamega. He sells mangoes to the local people. He has been doing this for three years now and says that his business is profitable. He describes himself as very hardworking and visionary.

The major challenge Victor faces is that there are other people in the area doing the same kind of business, so it is difficult to maintain customer loyalty. The customers’ purchasing power is also low. In addition, they don’t purchase mangoes a lot since nutrition is not something people in rural areas are really knowledgeable about. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well.

Victor is using his loan of 20,000 KES to buy more mangoes to meet customers' demands and with the hope of being able to supply fruit and vegetable vendors with mangoes in bulk in the future. He also hopes to buy land and build a house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes to sell

loans.name: Rosenie

texts.en:
Rosenie D. is 38 years old, married and has two children. She is from the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. She is involved in farming but also opened an eatery four years ago. While her husband mainly focuses on the farm, she cooks the food that she sells at her eatery. She also helps sell their harvest. She said she loves farming, but she has to think of ways to improve their family income.

Rosenie joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. Rosenie successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rosenie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm supplies and invest in her eatery. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and invest in her eatery

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem (on the left, raising her hand) is a wife of M. A., residing in a mid-sized city called Vehari in Pakistan. Vehari city is famous in Pakistan for its agricultural industry. 

Naseem is a housewife and prefers to spend her time at home taking care of her family while her husband operates a grocery shop in the market.  
He sells different daily-use items from his shop such as cooking oil, spices, soaps, and lentils to his customers. He is the only breadwinner of his family and because of this he works hard in improving his business. 

His shop does not quite have all the necessary items he needs for his customers. Because of this, he has started losing customers which is affecting his income. This is not a good sign for his business or his family.

That’s why Naseem is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for her husband’s grocery business. Her husband will use the loan to buy grocery items in bulk quantity in order to meet the requirements of his customers. Naseem is hopeful that through this investment her husband will successfully meet the requirements of his customers and retain his customer base as well.

loans.use: To buy grocery items in bulk quantity for her grocery business.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans O. J. is thirty years old and married. His wife is a businesswoman. They have one son, three years old, whom they hope to give quality education to through the university level. 

Evans' business is located at a busy town center called Kakamega. He provides motorcycle transport to the local people. He has been in this business for ten years now. In addition to his transport business, he also sells water to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. 

He will use this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (Kes) to purchase a motorcycle, which will add to his income. He hopes to grow his business, buy land, and build a house for his family, as well as help the needy in society. He describes himself as very hardworking and visionary.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Zulekha

texts.en:
Zulekha is a married woman with two children, one attending school and another still too young for school. She prepares food (french fries and flat bread) and sells it to her neighbors. With this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (Kes) she wants to purchase cooking oil, flour, and potatoes.

The challenge for her business is from the seasonality of her food, as she sells more in the afternoon than in the evening when her customers are in their homes preparing food for themselves. She has been in the business for six months and was a housewife before.

She rents her home and has electricity with no water. She cites her greatest expense as school fees. She joined Yehu for the financial support that they offer. Zulekha hopes to open a shop where she can start a clothing business.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, wheat flour, and sacks of potatoes.
